item.title: Economy | Historic US allies cede influence to China
item.description: The leaders of the United Kingdom and Canada “bowed to Beijing”, observed analyst Bill Bishop yesterday, in an analysis of recent diplomatic contacts with China, which reflect a distance from the United States. “We had two of the United States' staunchest historical allies, two members of NATO […] effectively, in a way, bowing down to Beijing”, commented the analyst in his daily bulletin Sinocism. Last week's visit by British Prime Minister Keir Starmer to the People's Republic of China – the first by a British head of government since 2018 – comes at a time when other Western leaders, such as those from France, Finland and Canada, are also seeking to strengthen ties with Beijing, in a trend towards diversifying alliances in the face of the unpredictability of North American foreign policy. Although Beijing did not announce any major concessions to the British delegation, Starmer returned to the United Kingdom with a reduction in tariffs on British whiskey from 10 percent to 5 percent and with the promise of new commercial partnerships. A business delegation of around 50 companies, including AstraZeneca, accompanied the head of Government, and an investment of 15 billion dollars in China until 2030 was announced. The visit was preceded by the approval, by the British authorities, of a project for a new Chinese embassy in London, blocked for several years, as well as the abandonment of a judicial process for espionage involving Chinese citizens. For Bishop, Beijing's strategy does not aim to replace the United States as these countries' main ally, but rather to “explore the space left by fissures” in traditional relations with Washington. Starmer's visit, like that of the Canadian Prime Minister, is interpreted as a sign of openness to more pragmatic relations with two members of NATO and the “Five Eyes” information alliance. “China continues to have a huge advantage in critical supply chains, such as rare earths,” recalled Bishop, referring to Chinese control over minerals essential to the industry. A recent report by the European Council on Foreign Relations (ECFR) think tank pointed in a similar direction. The document concluded that Donald Trump's unilateral and transactional foreign policy is causing a global realignment, with several countries considering China a more predictable and, in some cases, more trustworthy actor than the United States. Influence Maps According to ECFR, only 16 percent of Europeans today see the US as a reliable ally. Among respondents in 21 countries, only 10 percent believe that the US will have more influence in the world within 10 years, while 36 percent believe in China. The report also highlighted that many citizens, both in Europe and in the so-called Global South, no longer see the world divided between two rival blocs, but rather as a multipolar space, where it is possible to maintain good relations with both powers. For Bishop, China's objective is not to turn Western allies against Washington, but rather to take advantage of the divisions that have widened. “It’s not about turning them against the United States, but rather about expanding the space for influence and negotiation,” he stated.

item.title: Patriotism | Sam Hou Fai emphasizes priority to national interests
item.description: “We always put the safeguarding of sovereignty, security and national development interests first, resolutely implementing the principle of ‘Macau governed by patriots’”, stated the Chief Executive in a speech given yesterday at the reception of the Spring party hosted by the Liaison Office of the Central People's Government in the Macao SAR. Sam Hou Fai summarized last year's political action, with particular emphasis on national integration and defense of state security. "Within the scope of safeguarding national security, we took decisive measures, handling cases in accordance with the law, in order to resolutely prevent and prevent infiltration and interference by external forces. This ensured the effective maintenance of stability and harmony in Macau", said the local politician. The leader of the Executive mentioned Xi Jinping's instructions several times, namely the phrase, which has “always present”, “Prosperity should not induce complacency, nor does security justify forgetting danger”. Stating that 2026 is a crucial year for alignment with national strategies, Sam Hou Fai reinforced the promise to maintain stability. “We will continue to implement the principle of ‘one country, two systems’ in a comprehensive, precise and resolute manner, firmly safeguarding national sovereignty, security and development interests and resolutely upholding the insurmountable line that ‘there can be no chaos in Macau’.”

item.title: Game | Fewer illegal loans in 2025
item.description: Last year, the Judiciary Police initiated a total of 192 investigations related to illegal gambling loans, which represented a drop of 23.8 percent compared to 2024. The numbers were released yesterday during a symposium on last year's statistics. Despite there being fewer loans, the number of gambling-related investigations opened increased by 62.6 percent, to a total of 2,314. This increase was justified with the crime of illegally exchanging money for gambling. This was a practice that local authorities always understood was not necessary to criminalize. However, in 2024, after criticism from the Interior in which the practice of these money exchanges in Macau was identified as a vulnerability for the country's security, the Macao SAR Government ended up moving forward with criminalization. In the statements made, Sit Chong Meng, director of the PJ, stated that since the law combating illegal exchanges of money for gambling came into force until December 2025, 567 cases were concluded, which led to the arrest of 867 people. Police seized more than 94 million Hong Kong dollars, with some operations conducted in cooperation with Homeland authorities. According to the newspaper Ou Mun, the increase in crime also resulted from “statistical improvements”, which were not specified. Sit also warned that “as law enforcement initiatives intensify, the activities of money exchange gangs have become increasingly secretive and criminal patterns more sophisticated.” However, the person responsible promised that the PJ “will closely and persistently monitor” the criminal networks that use legitimate businesses to hide these illegal exchanges.

item.title: Chinese New Year | Votive papers session at Fundação Rui Cunha
item.description: The Rui Cunha Foundation (FRC) today hosts the second session of the “Fai Chun – Votive Paper Offering” initiative, in celebration of the Chinese New Year. Therefore, those interested and curious can stop by the gallery to receive the votive papers, which are messages of good luck in Chinese calligraphy, between 10am and 4pm. The papers are free, being an event co-organized by the Poetry Association of Friends of Jardim da Flora. The FRC welcomes 41 calligraphy masters and poets who will create happy phrases and verse couplets alluding to the celebrations of the New Lunar Year of the Horse. Fai Chun is a traditional decoration used during Chinese New Year, which marks the arrival of the spring season. In Portuguese it can be translated as Onda de Primavera. People place Fai Chun on doors to create a happy and festive atmosphere, as the calligraphed phrases mean good luck and prosperity. Normally, traditional Fai Chun are red in color, with black or gold characters inscribed with a brush, which aim to protect the houses with good wishes for the year ahead. Nowadays, printed versions are more common and produced on a large scale. They can be square or rectangular and hung vertically or horizontally, usually in pairs. They not only exist in China, but also in Korea, Japan and Vietnam. 2026 is the Year of the Fire Horse, which begins on February 17, 2026 (the first day of the Chinese New Year) and lasts until February 5, 2027. The Horse is the seventh of the 12 signs of the Chinese zodiac.

item.title: Emperor | Sold gold from the ground for 100 million
item.description: The Emperor group, responsible for the hotel with the same name in Macau, agreed to sell several gold bars that were placed on the hotel floor. The announcement was made yesterday to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, and the sale of the metal was agreed for 99.7 million Hong Kong dollars, which should represent a net profit of 90.2 million. Regarding the reasons for selling the gold, the group explains that it is part of a new strategy for operating the hotel, given the end of the operation of the gaming space, which in the past made the Emperor Hotel a satellite casino. “Following the closure of its gaming operations, the Group has been actively planning other entertainment and amusement facilities to enhance its overall hospitality experience and broaden its revenue base,” it was noted. “The precious metals that were originally part of the hotel’s interior design and equipment are no longer relevant to the hotel’s theme in the future,” it was added. The company's Board of Directors also explained that the sale is taking place at a time when the value of gold has reached historic figures. The buyer is the company Heraeus Metals Hong Kong, representing the German group Heraeus, founded in 1660, which is dedicated to activities such as trading precious metals, recycling, healthcare, electronic products and semiconductors.

item.title: MGM China | Profits rose 10.7 percent
item.description: The lion dealership announced annual revenue growth that promises an auspicious entry into the Year of the Horse. In 2025, MGM China announced record profits of $1.2 billion Macau gaming operator MGM China announced record profits of US$1.2 billion in 2025, an annual increase of 10.7 percent. This is the third consecutive year with a new maximum, after, in 2023, MGM China registered a historic record of earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization (EBITDA) of around 921 million dollars and, in 2024, approximately 1.13 million dollars. These data, according to a statement sent to the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday, were published “inadvertently”, as the publication date was scheduled for February 11th. The results, the company wrote, will be released today “after the market closes” Also according to the document, in the last quarter of last year, MGM China achieved profits of US$332.3 million, an increase of 30.5 percent compared to the same period last year (US$254.7 million). The company ended the year with an annual increase of 10.9 percent in revenue, with earnings of US$4.5 billion in 2025 compared to US$4.02 billion obtained in the previous year. In quarterly terms, MGM China achieved net revenues of US$1.24 billion in the last three months of the year, which represents an increase of 21.4 percent compared to the same period in 2024 (US$1.02 billion). Above expected In reaction to the announced results, cited by the GGR Asia portal, the financial services company Jefferies considered that they were between 3 percent and 5 percent above expectations. However, yesterday was marked by a suspension of trading in MGM China shares on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. The suspension took place in the morning, after the parent company, MGM Resorts, had “inadvertently” announced the results of MGM China, even before it was communicated to the Hong Kong Bola authorities. Six gaming concessionaires, MGM, Galaxy, Venetian, Melco, Wynn and SJM, operate in Macau, the only place in China where casino gambling is legal. Casinos in the region closed 2024 with revenue of 226.8 billion patacas, 23.9 percent more than in 2023 (183.1 billion patacas). Macau casino revenues reached 247.4 billion patacas last year, an increase of 9.1 percent compared to the previous year.

item.title: Hengqin New District | Less than 40% of homes sold
item.description: Until last January, 1,610 apartments had been sold to residents in the New Neighborhood of Macau in Hengqin, according to data revealed to HM. Between the end of 2024 and last month, 222 units were sold, less than the apartments sold in Macau in November alone The sale of apartments in the New District of Macau in Hengqin continues to follow a pace well below the local market, even with the crisis that the real estate sector is going through. According to data revealed by Macau Urban Renewal to HM, by January 2026, 1,610 apartments had been sold in the New Neighborhood of Macau to Macao SAR residents, which represents a proportion of 39.5 percent of the total available units. At the end of May last year, Macau Urban Renovation's annual report revealed that 1,388 apartments had been purchased in the Ilha da Montanha housing complex since they went on sale in November 2023, which represented only 34 percent of the total volume of units (4,070). All in all, between the end of 2024 and last month, 222 units were sold in the New Macau District in Hengqin, a volume lower than the sales recorded in Macau only last November, when data from the Financial Services Department revealed 238 units sold, despite the crisis affecting the real estate sector in the Macao SAR. House of talents The anemic sales record in the housing complex for Macau residents in the Hengqin Deep Cooperation Zone takes on a more serious tone given the lifting of restrictions that the Hengqin authorities have introduced since 2024. This week, it was announced that Macau residents can purchase two units in the housing complex. However, Hengqin authorities implemented successive measures to boost sales. The criteria have been adjusted, including the removal of the age limit, allowing minors to own property, the restriction on resale within five years of purchase has been removed, as well as the adjustment of the limit on purchasing residential units. Furthermore, in September 2025, Macau Urban Renewal announced the start of sales of units in Tower 11 of the housing complex, with prices at special discounts for parking spaces, renovation works and the purchase of household appliances. The public capital company also indicated to HM that 200 apartments were reserved and leased to “entities that meet the criteria” to house non-resident talent. The lease of these fractions in the New Neighborhood of Macau was established in the land use right transfer contract signed on April 21, 2020 for the project. The accommodation for these qualified staff was reserved in towers 17 and 18 of the housing complex.

item.title: Presidential | Portuguese choose President over the weekend
item.description: Tomorrow and Sunday, Portuguese people residing in Macau will be able to vote in the Consultado-Geral to choose the next President of the Portuguese Republic. The polls will be open on both days, from 8am to 7pm, after three days of early voting in which 78 voters participated, more than triple the number of those in the first round The Portuguese will once again be called upon to vote in the second round of elections to elect the next President of the Republic, in a vote contested between candidates from the Socialist Party (António José Seguro) and Chega (André Ventura). In the Macao SAR, Portuguese people will be able to vote on Saturday and Sunday, from 8am to 7pm, at the Consulate General of Portugal in Macau and Hong Kong, just like voters who will vote abroad in the various diplomatic missions around the world. Remember that only national citizens who are registered abroad will be able to vote. To choose the next President of the Republic, voters must present a citizen card, identity card, or document that has an up-to-date photograph and is usually used for identification (passport or driving license). On the 27th, 28th and 29th of January, the consulate general received voters who voted in advance. This modality of suffrage was open to voters due to "the exercise of public or private functions, representing a national team. In addition, students, researchers, teachers and research fellows at a higher education institution, patients undergoing treatment, or voters accompanying the aforementioned citizens were able to vote in advance. According to information revealed by the Consulate General of Portugal in Macau and Hong Kong to HM, 78 voters voted in advance in the second round, more than triple the number of early votes in the first round, when 25 early votes were counted. Local vs National In the first round, the votes counted in Macau gave an advantage to the PSD candidate, Luís Marques Mendes, with 47.19 percent of the votes, followed by the socialist António José Seguro (20.98 percent) and André Ventura with 12.4 percent. At national level, António José Seguro won the first round with 1,755,563 votes (31.11 percent), followed by André Ventura, with 1,327,021 votes (23.52 percent) and João Cotrim Figueiredo, with 903,057 votes (16 percent). Luís Marques Mendes ended up in fifth place, out of the second round with 637,442 votes (11.3 percent).

item.title: National Security | Lawyers excluded with no chance of appealing
item.description: Processes classified as national security will cover criminal cases, but can also extend to administrative and civil areas. Lawyers will be required to present information about households, such as nationality and foreign political connections Lawyers who are excluded from trials related to national security by the Macao SAR State Security Defense Commission (CDSE) are prevented from filing an appeal to challenge the decision. The information is contained in the Government's proposal published yesterday on the Legislative Assembly portal and which deprives defendants of the possibility of freely choosing any lawyer registered with the Macau Lawyers Association. According to the procedures defined in the bill, the State Security Defense Commission will choose the lawyer for the defendants “in judicial proceedings of any nature in which the competent authority has well-founded reasons to believe that there is a need to protect the interests of State security”. According to this formulation, the exclusion of a lawyer may occur in criminal proceedings, such as the one currently underway against former deputy Au Kam San, but also in administrative or even private law proceedings, if it is considered that in some way “there is a need to protect the interests of State security”. Within the scope of the ongoing process, even before being chosen as representative, the lawyer must go to court and inform the judge of his desire to be appointed as a representative of one of the parties involved. From this moment on, an analysis of the lawyer and his family begins, which may require the obligation to present elements such as the lawyer's own nationality, members of his family and connections with organizations or individuals abroad, among “others”. This formulation thus opens the door for family members to have to declare their affiliation with political parties outside Macau. However, the required elements are not specified in the proposed law. If the judge considers that the elements provided by the lawyers initially are not sufficient, he may also require the presentation of “other information that he considers essential for verification”. The Boss decides Once the information has been collected, the CDSE decides whether it considers that the lawyer corresponds to the will of the political power for the specific case, issuing an opinion granting or refusing the “special authorization to the judicial representative”. The criteria that will be adopted by the Chief Executive, the secretaries, advisors to the Central Government, who do not vote, and other members of the Government linked to the police and other entities were not revealed. However, the law eliminates the possibility of judicial appeal or challenge within the commission itself. The Government's proposal thus adopts the policy of the electoral law for deputies, with the difference that the removal of a lawyer from a specific case does not prevent him from practicing the profession, nor from submitting new requests in the future, without being “frozen” for five years. Contrary to what happens with judges, the diploma does not exclude the participation of Portuguese lawyers in processes of this nature. Outside the control of the courts The law also defines the powers of the CDSE, which will have the power to issue orders to all public entities involved with the objectives of defending the security of the State, ensuring the prosperity and stability of the Macao SAR and guaranteeing the legitimate rights and interests of the residents of the Macao SAR and other people in the SAR. The diploma also confirms the CDSE's competence to issue binding opinions in relation to the elections for the Chief Executive and the Legislative Assembly. However, the law brings something new: the principle that the authorities' decisions follow the CDSE's opinions, not accepting challenges or legal action, unless there is a legal norm providing for this appeal. The Sam Hou Fai Government's proposal also defines that the commission's work “is free from any interference from other entities or individuals in the Macao SAR”, with no public information about the commission or its work being made available. Within the scope of the principle of secrecy, the commission can also hire the workers it deems necessary, and carry out expenses without the need for disclosure. The accounts will only be analyzed by the Chief Executive, who also presides over the CDSE. Ongoing process The Government's proposal for the new CDSE law is justified in the documents sent to the Legislative Assembly with the need to improve the “legal system and reinforce the top structure of the State security defense system”, to “firmly safeguard the sovereignty, security and development interests of the State, build a solid barrier to defend the State's security and maintain the general stability of society”. The Executive also indicates that the changes aim to “effectively prevent and repress external interference and ensure that the State’s security interests are not harmed”. The proposed law enters the hemicycle at a time when the investigation into former deputy Au Kam San is expected to be concluded, the only case made public in the Macao SAR related to national security. Arrested in July last year, the Democrat has been in pre-trial detention ever since. If the law is approved before a possible trial, the process may follow the stipulations of the diploma.

item.title: Diocese of Macau/450 years | New Catholic Center will have a hotel
item.description: The new Catholic Center should open “in the middle of the second quarter” of this year and will have a hotel, prepared to receive “pilgrims and tourists”, says the Diocese of Macau. At a time when the institution celebrates 450 years, the inauguration of the Catholic Center is based on “the vision” of D. Paulo José Tavares, bishop of Macau in the 60s and 70s After many years of emptiness and construction work on the corner of Avenida da Praia Grande and Rua do Campo, the new Catholic Center is preparing to open its doors later this year and is perhaps the most important event in the celebration of the 450th anniversary of the Diocese of Macau. HM asked questions to the Diocese of Macau regarding the reopening of the building, which confirmed that the official opening is scheduled “for the second quarter” of this year. This building, with a total of 17 floors, will have features designed for religious purposes, but also a hotel prepared to receive all types of people. "The Catholic Center will be a nerve center for disseminating and sharing the mission of the Catholic Church. The lower floors will feature a chapel, an auditorium, conference rooms, exhibition areas and spaces for activities." While “the upper floors will function as a hotel, offering welcoming and comfortable accommodation, imbued with a spirit of service”. In the diocese's written response, it is added that the hotel facilities “were designed to receive both pilgrims and tourists, welcoming Catholics and non-Catholics with hospitality and inclusion”. It is worth remembering that in December employees began to be recruited for the hotel unit, in partnership with the Directorate of Services for Labor Affairs (DSAL). In a job matching session aimed at residents, held on December 5th, with the “Companhia de Gestão do Centro Católico”, 23 job openings were made available for sales manager, assistant reception manager, chef, head of security, room service supervisor and acquisition supervisor, reads the DSAL note released in November. The Diocese of Macau did not want to tell HM how much it would cost to rebuild the new Catholic Center, saying only that initial forecasts had slipped due to the pandemic. "The Catholic Center is currently undergoing development and submission and approval by the Government. Following the challenges of the Covid-19 pandemic, construction costs have increased significantly. We are grateful for the understanding and support of the builders and contractors, which allowed the reconstruction project to be completed successfully. At the same time, we warmly welcome donations from all sectors of society to help sustain and carry forward the Catholic Center's original mission of serving the Macau community." A bishop still present Asked about the main goals of the new Catholic Center, the Diocese of Macau describes that the building “aims to continue the spiritual mission of the Catholic Church and incorporate the spirit of Christ”, influenced by the work of Bishop D. Paulo José Tavares, who carried out his mission in Macau in the mid-20th century. Of particular note is the fact that D. Paulo José Tavares, who died in 1973 and was appointed Bishop of Macau in 1961, was important in maintaining the presence of the Catholic Church in Macau at the time of the “1,2,3” movement. Between November 1966 and February 1967, the Cultural Revolution manifested itself in the territory, bringing together many local students, who intended to change the content of Catholic education. D. Paulo José Tavares fought with these groups of protesters, managing to keep teaching in Catholic schools and the spirit associated with them unchanged. In this way, and based on “the vision” of this bishop, the diocese intends for the new Catholic Center to “continue to serve as a vital bridge for the Macau community, promoting dialogue, exchange and integration of faith and culture”. It is also the intention to “open the doors [of the Center] to visitors from all over the world, reinforcing not only its role as a spiritual refuge, but also infusing new vitality into the religious and cultural panorama of Macau”. António Pedro Costa, author of the cleric's biography, entitled “D. Paulo José Tavares – The diplomat bishop”, described, in an interview with HM in 2023, that the bishop “was a breath of fresh air”, and a figure cherished by the Chinese community at the time. "These attitudes of valuing the Chinese community led to a rapprochement and the establishment of a relationship of trust. Only in this way was he able to take his objectives forward, as he realized that he had to have the population on his side. But this caused him a lot of trouble with the European clergy, who did not agree with D. Paulo José Tavares' stance. It meant that the population saw him as an ally and not a person who comes from outside and imposes his ideas", said the author. A year of celebrations It was in 1576, in the fourth year of the Wanli reign, of the Ming Dynasty, that the Diocese was founded in Macau, with January 23rd being the official date of celebration. However, the next few months will also be festive. In a previously released statement, the Diocese of Macau states that it has had, over the years, “the mission of establishing bridges between East and West, promoting education, charity and pastoral service”, leaving “a deep and lasting mark on the cultural, educational and religious development of Macau”. The theme of the celebrations is “From Macau to the World: 450 years of Mission and Mercy”. The new Catholic Center will host two thematic exhibitions, entitled “Honoring the Past, Creating the Future” and “Witness to Heritage, Mission in the World”. These exhibitions aim to “reflect the development of the Diocese from historical, personal and cultural perspectives, as well as its future directions”, highlights the same note. Tomorrow a sacred music concert will take place at the Sé Church with eight choral groups from Macau, Hong Kong and the Province of Guangzhou, with the sounds of the church's new pipe organ being heard. From 7:30 pm onwards, the Diocesan Choir of Macau, the Cathedral Schola ensemble and other choral groups from Macau will perform, such as Coro Perosi, Dolce Voce and Cantate Chorus, without forgetting other ensembles from Hong Kong and Guangzhou. The Diocese highlights that the “most symbolic and large-scale initiative of the commemorative year” will be the “great celebration” scheduled for October 31st this year, which consists of a reception and mass. “Through this solemn celebration, the Diocese will give thanks to God for the graces and mission granted over four and a half centuries, and will pray that He continues to guide the way forward”, the same statement describes. There will also be initiatives carried out by “various diocesan institutions” in the coming months, namely “cultural shows, school competitions, academic symposiums, social activities, youth meetings, online training resources, parish initiatives and liturgical celebrations”. “Through transversal and intergenerational participation, the commemorative year seeks to deepen public knowledge about the historical development of the Diocese and its service to the community, promoting the spirit of the diocesan motto ‘Scientia et Virtus’ (Science and Virtue), which inspires a practice of service based on the balance between knowledge and ethical care.” At a time when it celebrates 450 years of existence, the Diocese says it wants to chart the future, “walking with the residents of Macau in reflecting on the past and continuing its mission of faith, service and culture in this new stage”.

They not only exist in China, but also in Korea, Japan and Vietnam. 2026 is the Year of the Fire Horse, which begins on February 17, 2026 (the first day of the Chinese New Year) and lasts until February 5, 2027. The Horse is the seventh of the 12 signs of the Chinese zodiac.

item.title: Boi Warehouse | Three artists present new visions of Macau
item.description: Armazém do Boi reveals, from the 13th of February, the works of three Chinese artists who carried out artistic residencies in the territory and who, with their art, outlined new visions of the territory they temporarily inhabited. “O Viajante da Montagem”, “Waste: Soup without Water” and “With Who I Am” are the results of this type of fieldwork Armazém do Boi has long accustomed us to bringing new visions of the territory with the work of local artists, but also from abroad. The new triptych of exhibitions, to be opened on the 13th of February, will once again reveal to the public new readings about this common and shared space that is Macau. One of the exhibitions is by artist Liao Yu-An, entitled “The Drifter of Assemblage – Red and Blue, Color Fields and Monsters”. This is the result of a month of experiences in Macau, where the artist “gained awareness of the fragmented and complex nature of the city”. In Armazém do Boi's note about this exhibition, it is described that Liao Yu-An sees Macau as “a place where scales oscillate between the miniature and the monumental”, and where “multiple facets coexist in dense proximity, resembling a richly layered and intensely flavorful stew”. In this presentation, “the artist absorbs and reflects on these sensory impressions, translating them into different pictorial expressions”. More specifically, what the public will be able to see are three sets of works that examine “the mechanisms of transformation between visual signs, urban color structures and a subjective perceptual experience”. Here, painting is nothing more than “a practice of perceptual translation and experiential reconstruction”. "Between montage and transformation, painting stops being just a means of representing reality, becoming a continuous action that generates perception. Colors, images and fragmented experiences intertwine to form a fluid trajectory of visualization, guiding the public on a sensorial journey situated between the city, the body and the imagination", the same note describes. Another work that will be presented from the 13th is “Residues: Soup without Water” [Dregs: Soup without Water], by Biyi Zhu, curated and academic work by Vivien Chan. In this exhibition, there are meanings that are taken from a kind of imaginary dictionary, in which waste is seen as “the last drop, grain or molecule spread at the bottom of the pan”. “Residues: Soup without Water” refers to what remains “after all the soup has been eaten”, looking at the “soft and moist consistency” of the waterless remains of a soup traditionally prepared according to the rules of Cantonese cuisine. Thus, Biyi Zhu asks: “What are the possibilities of what remains?”, clinging, through art, to “the remains of the past”. This is a return to Macau after a ten-year stay in the Netherlands, and in this exhibition, “Zhu uses the processes and materialities of Cantonese soup to explore ways of traveling in time, between places, relationships and lives”. "After drinking the soup, the residue becomes proof of what was absorbed by the body, by the atmosphere. Taking what would normally be discarded, Zhu transforms the residue into tangible forms, dissolving and reformulating ideas of memory, kinship, migration and waste", it further reads. Personal issues The third exhibition space is composed of “Who Am I With”, by Li Aixiao, curated by Wendy Wong. This is an exhibition with a more personal nature, which begins with the artist’s “self”, when he “enters the lives, languages ​​and objects of others”. To do this, he uses performance, photography and other artistic interactions “to persistently question with whom and how we establish connections in this place”. "The works unfold between the approaching and distancing of the body and between the occurrence and interruption of exchange, where some connections take root while others remain in the realm of the unfulfilled. As viewers navigate and observe, they perceive the transitory transformation of identity and the emergence or absence of intimacy, witnessing how language, images and objects serve as modes of presence", it is described. In this way, “these works point to a state of coexistence that remains perpetually unstable, but that occasionally awakens rare and authentic connections at the moment of encounter”. The three exhibitions can be seen free of charge until March 15th.

item.title: Mineral trade | Beijing rejects fragmentation after US initiative
item.description: China yesterday rejected the creation of exclusive “small circles” in international trade in critical minerals and advocated an “open, inclusive and universally beneficial” trading environment, in response to US-led initiatives. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian said at a press conference that “maintaining an open, inclusive and universally beneficial international trade environment serves the common interests of all countries”. Lin further stressed that “all parties have a responsibility to play a constructive role” to safeguard the stability and security of global production and supply chains for critical minerals. The spokesperson added that China “opposes any country harming the international economic and commercial order through exclusive ‘small circles’ rules”, in an indirect reference to the cooperation mechanisms promoted by Washington with partners and allies to reduce China's dependence in this sector. The statements come after the United States announced the creation of a commercial alliance for critical minerals and Washington and the European Union agreed on a first joint action plan to coordinate supply policies for these raw materials, considered essential for industries such as semiconductors, advanced batteries and defense. Beijing reiterated in recent days that its position on the stability of global supply chains “has not changed” and defended the strengthening of communication and dialogue between countries, to the detriment of formulas that “fragment international trade”.

item.title: Airport | CAM aims for 8.14 million passengers in 2026
item.description: After a year of 2025 in which the airport lost passengers and commercial flights, those responsible for CAM – Sociedade do Aeroporto Internacional de Macau believe that 2026 will be different. According to figures presented during a Lunar New Year lunch, organized yesterday, the company estimates it will receive 8.14 million passengers and 63,000 commercial flight arrivals and departures throughout this year. The numbers indicated by the company, and cited by the newspaper Ou Mun, represent an annual increase of 8.2 percent in the number of passengers and 8.6 percent in the number of arrivals and departures of commercial flights. The annual estimate for the number of passengers in 2026 is still below what happened before the pandemic. In 2019, the airport received a total of 9.61 million passengers, the highest figure since it began operating, and in the previous year it had received 8.26 million passengers. The increase in the number of passengers is expected, despite the chairman of the company's Executive Committee, Simon Chan Weng Hong, having revealed that from October this year until October 2029 the airport will be closed between night and 8am. The closure was justified by the expansion of infrastructure and landfill. Regarding these works, Simon Chan stated that a “minimal impact” on the operation of the airport is expected. The president of the CAM Executive Committee also revealed that new restaurants will open at the airport in April, offering meals prepared by some of the best-known local brands.

item.title: Today Macau
item.description: The leaders of the United Kingdom and Canada “bowed to Beijing”, observed analyst Bill Bishop yesterday, in an analysis of recent diplomatic contacts with China, which reflect a distance from the United States. “We had two of the United States' staunchest historical allies, two members of NATO […] effectively, in a way, bowing down to Beijing”, commented the analyst in his daily bulletin Sinocism. Last week's visit by British Prime Minister Keir Starmer to the People's Republic of China – the first by a British head of government since 2018 – comes at a time when other Western leaders, such as those from France, Finland and Canada, are also seeking to strengthen ties with Beijing, in a trend towards diversifying alliances in the face of the unpredictability of North American foreign policy. Although Beijing did not announce any major concessions to the British delegation, Starmer returned to the United Kingdom with a reduction in tariffs on British whiskey from 10 percent to 5 percent and with the promise of new commercial partnerships. A business delegation of around 50 companies, including AstraZeneca, accompanied the head of Government, and an investment of 15 billion dollars in China until 2030 was announced. The visit was preceded by the approval, by the British authorities, of a project for a new Chinese embassy in London, blocked for several years, as well as the abandonment of a judicial process for espionage involving Chinese citizens. For Bishop, Beijing's strategy does not aim to replace the United States as these countries' main ally, but rather to “explore the space left by fissures” in traditional relations with Washington. Starmer's visit, like that of the Canadian Prime Minister, is interpreted as a sign of openness to more pragmatic relations with two members of NATO and the “Five Eyes” information alliance. “China continues to have a huge advantage in critical supply chains, such as rare earths,” recalled Bishop, referring to Chinese control over minerals essential to the industry. A recent report by the European Council on Foreign Relations (ECFR) think tank pointed in a similar direction. The document concluded that Donald Trump's unilateral and transactional foreign policy is causing a global realignment, with several countries considering China a more predictable and, in some cases, more trustworthy actor than the United States. Influence Maps According to ECFR, only 16 percent of Europeans today see the US as a reliable ally. Among respondents in 21 countries, only 10 percent believe that the US will have more influence in the world within 10 years, while 36 percent believe in China. The report also highlighted that many citizens, both in Europe and in the so-called Global South, no longer see the world divided between two rival blocs, but rather as a multipolar space, where it is possible to maintain good relations with both powers. For Bishop, China's objective is not to turn Western allies against Washington, but rather to take advantage of the divisions that have widened. “It’s not about turning them against the United States, but rather about expanding the space for influence and negotiation,” he stated.

item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Jiang Shinian, also known as Shennong, the «Divine Farmer», patron saint of practitioners of traditional medicine (zhongyi), is also known as Yandi, the «emperor of flames» and is therefore able to control the «flaming wind», the excess heat that causes symptoms such as tremors, confusion or sudden fever. In religious practice, this “fire in the wind” is understood as the smoke that results from the burning of incense or papers that carry prayers, offerings or messages to the gods, ancestors or spirits up to the heavens. This fire, represented by the color red, is associated, among others, with immortality, positive energy forces or protection against evil. Shades of the color red were notoriously adopted by the emperors of the Ming dynasty who had Zhu, “vermilion or cinnabar” as their family name. One of the most publicly manifest examples was painting the walls of the “Forbidden Imperial City”, Zijincheng, purple, as a form of protection for the occupants inside, or giving the clothing of literate officials the color of cinnabar. When the dynasty fell and for many literati it became intolerable to obey the new emperors, some adopted the most diverse and subtle strategies of resistance. A scholar from the North who, in the plurality of his knowledge and vocations, came to use more than thirty names of brush, created for himself the name Zhuyi daoren, the «Daoist dressed in cinnabar» as if by using this protective color, he only recognized his own body as the only border or wall. In ordinary life, his name was Fu Shan (1607-1684), born in Yangqu, Shanxi, and from his refusal to serve his new masters, which harmed his day-to-day life, countless talents emerged, still celebrated today in two gardens in the city of Taiyuan, the provincial capital. And although all the literati who knew him recognized his qualities as a calligrapher, painter or poet, those closest to him saw him as a practitioner of traditional medicine, in particular as an expert on women's illnesses. Fu Shan preferred his handwriting to be “rough, not skillful; ugly, not seductive; deformed, not thin; spontaneous, not premeditated». And just like in paintings, he liked long vertical formats, as can be seen in a couplet in the Smithonian (ink on paper, 226 x 45.5 cm) where, reflecting his dual concern with the spirit and the body, he wrote: «If the spirit is calm, the mind naturally reaches the distance; The more relaxed your body is, the more of life you will be able to enjoy». He is credited with creating an “eight treasure soup”, made with eight ingredients that restored the most weakened. And yet, when he was forced to go to court in Beijing for the ritual of obedience to the new dynasty, he threw himself to the ground, suffering an incapacitating illness. Walking along the riverbank, enjoying the flowers, 6 (out of 7): Access to Huangsi's in-laws' house it is full of flowers everywhere, There are a thousand, ten thousand flowers pressing the branches, so full, bent. Repeatedly invite the butterflies to stay constantly dancing, I listen to orioles: how they are tuned in your delicate chirp. Du Fu (712-770)

item.title: History | Book reveals how Macau was created in the image of Évora
item.description:
The local association Heritage Society has just released a two-volume book on the history of Macau's founding. Authored by Caspar Chan and Nathan Rubene dos Santos, “Foral of the City of the Name of the God, Macau”, contains translations and annotations of documents that show how the founding of Macau had Évora as a model
A book, divided into two volumes, has just been published by the local association Heritage Society, which helps tell the story of the founding of Macau, from the mid-16th century onwards. The two volumes are entitled “Foral of the City of the Name of the God, Macau: Évora of the Far East” and “The Twenty-eight Alvarás”, and are authored by academics Caspar Chan and Nathan Rubene dos Santos. The first volume, which establishes a curious connection between Macau and Évora in the founding of the territory to the East, is based on the archive “Foral, Regalias e Privilégios Concedidos à Cidade de Macau, na China, 1596-1756”, the original of which is kept at the National Archives of Rio de Janeiro, and there are microfilms at the Macau Archive. In turn, the part dedicated to the 28 charters, a continuation of the first volume, analyzes the 28 legal texts initially decreed by the then governor of Macau and viceroy of India, D. Rodrigo da Costa, in 1689. These documents were later confirmed by King D. João V, in Portugal, in 1709. As the authors told HM, in a joint email interview, the first volume “deals with the first part of the archive, or the first 17 sheets, which concern the oldest founding letters, letters and sentences received by the Senate of Macau during the last years of the 16th century”. The second volume analyzes the contents of the file between pages 17 and 33, covering the 28 permits. “This is not yet the complete story, as we intend to continue working on the remaining archive in future years”, confessed the authors. The authors highlight the importance of the charter, an ancient document that consisted of “a charter or contract that the governing power, be it a feudal lord, a bishop or a king, establishes with a local entity, be it a village or city, a senate or a council”. "We consider that the word and the concept are important to reflect on this historical period and not only in Macau, but also the time when the European kingdom [Portugal] was at the height of its expansion across the seas and oceans. The concept of charter implies the way in which a Portuguese social structure was being transplanted and rethought in Macau." In this way, the authors add, all documents analyzed for these two volumes are related to the idea of ​​charter. In turn, the designation “City of the Name of God of Macau” appears, in this specific file, “not only in the charter of King Philip I of Portugal, during the Iberian Union, which stipulates the elevation of Macau from a town to a city, but also throughout the 28 subsequent charters”. In concrete terms, readers can come across “a research work that addresses some of the most important documents in the history of Macau, documents that inform us about the founding of the city and the evolution of its legal and governing tradition”. The connection with Évora The first volume of the work includes the subtitle “Évora of the Far East”, relating “the story in which the town's Senate presented a petition to the Viceroy of India for the recognition of the Senate, for the elevation of this port to the status of city and for the granting to the 'new city' of Macau of the privileges, rights and freedoms of the city of Évora”. D. Duarte de Meneses, at the time governor of Macau and viceroy of India, ended up granting this request on behalf of King D. Filipe I, in 1586, a “decision that was later confirmed by the king himself in 1595”. “To confirm and corroborate that Macau had the same status as Évora, it became natural that all the founding documents of the city of Évora were transcribed to Macau, so that the Senate of Macau could preserve them as evidence and keep them in its archives as founding documents of the city”, explain the authors. The documents found in the archive based in Rio de Janeiro point out that “the ‘proof’ of Macau’s status as a city comparable to Évora does not consist of a single document, but a compilation of several texts”. In the first volume of the work there are examples such as “sentences on the jurisdiction of certain positions, such as the Prosecutor and the Almotacé, royal letters on specific issues, laws on which positions should be part of a Senate, rites of religious and funeral processions and even the configuration of the Senate room”. In short, “everything that Évora possessed de jure during this period was inherited by Macau, as proven by the meticulous transcription and authentication of these documents”, explain the authors. The survival permits Regarding the second volume of the work, focused on the 28 permits, the authors understand that these documents “are particularly significant because they present themselves as a cohesive set, with great integrity in terms of language, format, administration and argumentation”. For Caspar Chan and Nathan Rubene dos Santos, this results from the fact that, at the end of the 17th century, Macau was no longer in its golden period of trade, “due to the loss of commercial routes”. "At the same time, Macau faced constant social unrest, both internally – for example, between the Senate, the Captain-General and the Ouvidor – and externally, in relations with the Chinese and Castilians. The privileges and rights of the Senate were not respected, and it was necessary to resolve ambiguities to guarantee the city's survival, as reflected in the various minutes of the Senate meetings." Thus, a petition was presented by these bodies to governor D. Rodrigo da Costa “for the reaffirmation of the city's rights and to present solutions to various problems, such as the overflow of the jurisdiction of the Captain-General, the preservation of the Padroado in the face of foreign missionary groups and trade with the Chinese and in Solor and Timor”. Thus, the 28 permits emerged, which “also deal with a very diverse group of people from different arts, professions, origins and ideologies”, and not just relations between Portuguese and Chinese, which made “this set of documents particularly interesting to study”. The aim of publishing these two volumes was to facilitate access to the archive and its information. “We intend to place in the hands of Macau readers a fundamental document of the legal and political origin of the city, which remains little studied, even in Portuguese-speaking historiography, and which is almost completely absent from the daily historical imagination of Macau”, they add. The archive based in Rio de Janeiro was translated by the authors “and was never published in full, especially the founding documents related to Évora, not even in Portuguese”. This archive almost always appears “indirectly, as excerpts and paraphrases, such as those of canonical historians of Macau, in the case of Manuel Teixeira; or as references inserted in specialized works, and in some cases only through digitalized transcriptions that circulate in doctoral theses”. In the case of permits, they are “better known among historians, but appear only in very limited publications”. "For this reason, the publication of the primary text itself becomes essential. By presenting it in English and Chinese, alongside Portuguese, we also seek to remove a barrier that has long structured Macau's historiography, dividing the city's documentary past into separate linguistic archives that rarely dialogue with each other", they conclude. Caspar Chan and Nathan Rubene dos Santos also understand that “these volumes offer new answers in historiographical terms, because they show with renewed clarity that the legal existence of Macau emerged through the transplantation and local adaptation of the Portuguese municipality [Évora] as a governing idea on an Asian border”. “At its core, the archive poses a fundamental question that often remains implicit: what counted as ‘Portuguese territory’ in its smallest civic unit, and how could this unit be reconstructed overseas through privileges, positions and jurisdiction, after Portugal had become global from the 15th century onwards?” Local management Regarding the relationship between Portugal and China at the time, the authors state that the work shows how “relations between China and Portugal in Macau were not carried out mainly through formal diplomacy between two distant courts, but through the daily management of coexistence by local institutions, in conditions of unequal jurisdiction”. The first volume of the book shows how “the king elevated Macau from a town to a city and confirmed the elections of councillors, judges and officials because the Captain-Major appointed to China frequently left for the annual trip to Japan, remaining only a short time there and leaving the settlement without continuous leadership”. The original document reveals that “this situation was especially dangerous in China, given Macau's distance from India and the fact that supplies could only be made during the annual trip”. In this way, “municipal government is presented as a necessity: a frontier city could not wait for an absent commander nor could it allow disorder.” Thus, the authors add, “the privileges, jurisdiction and civic positions granted to Macau describe a political logic as much as a legal one, since the Portuguese presence depended on a permanent local body capable of maintaining peace and managing risks in a space where the superior authority was distant”. Regarding the permits, they show what maintaining the stability of the territory entailed, as “the survival of Macau depended on remaining within the limits tolerated by the Chinese authority”. "The Twenty-sixth Alvará, for example, is explicit in stating that the Chinese mandarinate did not accept Portuguese jurisdiction over Chinese subjects, especially when Christian creditors sought to arrest Chinese debtors. The Senate describes the expenses and dangers caused when a mandarin was sent to enforce such determinations and requests a direct solution: preventing Christians from contracting credits with the Chinese and denying them recourse to both the Ombudsman and the Chinese courts, so that the city could 'live in peace’. The Crown confirms this approach”, they conclude.

item.title: Elections | Portugal prepares to choose the next President of the Republic
item.description:
Portugal goes to the vote on Sunday to choose the next President of the Republic. Of the 11 candidates, only two have representatives from Macau: Bessa Almeida from the PSD, and Neto Valente from the PS. The former president of the Macau Lawyers Association highlights that António José Seguro “does not join in provocations against China”, while Bessa Almeida considers that Marques Mendes is the right man for the moment
Eleven candidates will vote on Sunday to choose the next President of the Portuguese Republic, for a five-year term. This is a record number, with only seven having the support of political parties. Running for the position is Luís Marques Mendes, supported by the Social Democratic Party (PSD), and who appointed António Bessa Almeida as his representative in the Macao SAR. Next comes António José Seguro, with the support of the Socialist Party (PS), which has Jorge Neto Valente, president of the Macau Portuguese School Foundation and lawyer, as his representative. They are the only candidates for the Presidency of the Republic who chose figures as representatives of the Macao SAR. The remaining candidates are Henrique Gouveia e Melo, João Cotrim de Figueiredo, Catarina Martins, António Filipe, André Ventura Jorge Pinto, Manuel João Vieira, André Pestana and Humberto Correia. To HM, António Bessa Almeida, PSD activist and explained the reasons for supporting Marques Mendes. “At the time Portugal is going through, the country needs a candidate like Marques Mendes, who has a deep understanding of the different policies”, he began by pointing out. Asked about the type of actions developed in Macau to attract the electorate to vote for Marques Mendes, Bessa Almeida simply mentioned that “the campaign in Macau is totally different from that in Portugal”, and the actions developed involve “what the candidate does in close proximity to the people, passing on information”. For Bessa Almeida, “the electorate in Macau, on the Chinese side, is also made up of Portuguese”, and that “they have been following these elections like any other Portuguese, with confident visions for the future of Portugal”. On January 6th, the president released a note highlighting the importance of Marques Mendes' candidacy, who is currently far from the top spots in the polls. "We have always been concerned with everything related to Portugal and at this moment, at a global level, political changes are sudden and unexpected. That is why we need a visionary president, experienced and thoughtful in guiding the destinies of Portugal and Portuguese people born and living outside the country."
A safe return In Portugal, polls relating to the presidential elections have taken place almost daily, and show a change in the choice of candidates. If initially António José Seguro was somewhat removed from the top positions, a survey carried out by the Universidade Católica Portuguesa for RTP, Antena 1 and the Público newspaper, between the 6th and 9th of January and released this week, shows how Seguro is in a technical tie with André Ventura, Chega's candidate, guaranteeing 23 percent of voting intentions, when Ventura collects 24 percent. João Cotrim de Figueiredo comes in third place, with 19 percent, with the possibility of going to the second round of elections, followed by Marques Mendes and Gouveia e Melo with 14 percent. Another survey, this time for TVI, CNN, TSF and Jornal de Notícias, with data collected on the 10th, 11th and 12th of January, shows Seguro with 23.9 percent of voting intentions, followed by Cotrim de Figueiredo with 20.8 percent and Ventura with 20.5 percent. Marques Mendes falls to fifth place, with 13.2 percent. Seguro chose, in the Macao SAR, Jorge Neto Valente as his agent, who did not answer HM's call. In a statement published in the newspapers this Wednesday, the former president of the Macau Lawyers Association declared that Seguro “proposes a vision of the future based on the modernization of the country, the valorization of education and a focus on innovation”. Referring specifically to Portugal-China relations, Neto Valente highlights that “unlike other candidates, Seguro does not support China's provocations regarding the status of Taiwan, and is also a candidate who “knows Portugal, Europe and the world”. Neto Valente also stated that Seguro “is a decent man”. “He participated in all debates, showed politeness, defended his ideas firmly, was never excessive in his language and, unlike others, did not insult opponents or make malicious insinuations toward them.”
A “consistent course” Paulo Pisco, leader of the Insurance campaign for emigration, reminded HM that the candidate “even expressed the opinion that, given that it was an in-person vote [for the presidential elections], the Government could have done much more, namely complying with what the electoral law for the Presidency of the Republic says, which is the possibility of opening more polling stations”. Seguro also defended, according to Paulo Pisco, “that mobility voting could also have been applied, based on the experience previously carried out in the last elections for the European Parliament”. Paulo Pisco states that António José Seguro has followed a “very consistent, solid and objective path”, which has allowed him to reach the top of the polls. Regarding the emigrated electorate, the deputy highlights that Seguro “has not deviated from the purposes, form and values ​​with which he intends to exercise the Presidency of the Republic”. Furthermore, it is “a guarantor of the stability of the political system and also of democracy”. “This image that the candidate António José Seguro has shown throughout his career has earned him greater receptivity from voters”, highlighted Paulo Pisco. The president does not forget that “Seguro is the candidate who has the most representatives per country in our diaspora”. "There are 18, ten in Europe and eight outside Europe. I believe that this substantiates a very firm commitment from the candidate to the exercise of his functions as President of the Republic, and to the relationship he intends to have with the diaspora", he stressed. Looking at the candidates lower down in the polls, we have many faces from the left. The same survey with data collected on the 10th, 11th and 12th of January places Catarina Martins, from Bloco de Esquerda, with 2.5 percent; followed by António Filipe, from PCP, with 1.4 percent, head to head with Jorge Pinto, from Livre, who has 1.3 percent. Manuel João Vieira, visual artist and musician, obtains 1 percent of voting intentions.

item.title: Estudo | Sociedade de Hong Kong domina notícias sobre depressão
item.description: A study published in the Journal of Medical Internet Research analyzed the themes and emotional tone of news stories about depression published in Hong Kong. The “societal system”, related to health, family or work, comes first with 34.83 percent of total news, having a “more negative inclination” The Hong Kong society system dominates the group of topics present in news about depression, representing 34.83 percent of the articles analyzed, followed by topics such as law enforcement, with 18.81 percent, or the global economic recession in third place. This is the main conclusion of the study “Analyzing Themes, Feelings, and Coping Strategies Regarding Online News Coverage of Depression in Hong Kong: Mixed Methods Study”, published in the Journal of Medical Internet Research last year. The study was authored by Chen Sihui, Cindy Sing and Yangna Hu, from Hong Kong Polytechnic University; and Cecília Cheng, from the University of Hong Kong. The study is focused on online news coverage about depression in the neighboring region, namely from publications such as the South China Morning Post and Hong Kong Free Press, and sought to understand the dominant themes and the emotional charge of the texts, whether they were positive or negative, among other issues. Thus, the study reveals that the region's “societal system” was at the origin of 34.83 percent of news about depression, that is, 848 out of a total of 2,435, followed by the theme of “law enforcement”, representing 458 of all news analyzed, with a share of 18.81 percent. This is followed, in third place, by the theme of “global recession”, with 17.4 percent of responses; “lifestyle”, with 8.05 percent; “leisure”, with 11.21 percent of responses; “health issues”, with 6.94 percent and, finally, “United States politics”, representing just 3.12 percent of the news. The study therefore describes that analyzing the sentiment inherent to the news, “it becomes evident that the societal system presented a more negative inclination”, being “related to several systems of Hong Kong society, including health, social, family, education and work”. Between extradition and covid-19 The collection of online news was carried out between February 2019 and May 2024 “with the aim of examining the most recent representation of depression, especially during and after the period of social unrest and the covid-19 pandemic”. The articles were chosen based on three criteria, one of which was accessibility to readers without a paid subscription, in addition to the fact that the website in question “should allow the retrieval of a sufficient quantity of depression-related news (i.e., more than 20) to ensure adequate data for subsequent analyses.” Websites with news in English were also chosen. Then, separate searches were carried out using the keywords “depression” and “depressed”. The dates chosen for this study relate to two events. One of them was in February 2019, with the introduction of the proposed law on extradition to China, entitled “Fugitive Offenders and Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters Legislation (Amendment)”. This “triggered protests and marches in Hong Kong due to political differences, leading to a significant increase in cases of depression, worsened in 2020 with the outbreak of Covid-19”. The authors reveal that there were “peaks in coverage” of news related to depression, namely in April and May 2020 and in July 2023. Covid-19 followed as a second occurrence. In the case of news from 2020, the study finds that “confinement measures due to covid-19 strongly affected Hong Kong, contributing to a more depressive mood”, and this period “corresponded to the second wave of the covid-19 outbreak”. The second pandemic wave led to strong confinement measures such as the closure of schools, “remote work policies and the ban on in-person meals in restaurants”. The closure of schools, “as reported in the news, resulted in increased rates of depression among children and anxiety among parents, who had to simultaneously care for their children and elderly people at home.” “In addition, conflicts between work and family also intensified due to the interruption of the normal work routine”, namely “the absence of office space and unclear working hours”, which “was associated with depressive feelings”, it is described. In turn, in 2023 there was an “increase in reported suicide cases”, especially because Coco Lee, “an influential star who faced depression, died by suicide at home, which generated greater awareness about the need to expand support services in the area of ​​mental health and improve accessibility, with helplines frequently being highlighted”. A certain stigma With regard to the second most common topic found in the news, “law enforcement”, the study highlights that it also causes “a negative feeling”. “The volume of news reached peaks in November 2020 and August 2019”, and in 2020, “individual crimes and legal proceedings were mainly reported, with emphasis on the case of a Hong Kong teacher who murdered his wife, which may have caused a great social shock and public attention”. The authors explain that, in this case, “depression was frequently cited in the news as an explanation for the perpetrator's illegal actions, which can reinforce stigmatizing attitudes and portray people with depression as violent, dangerous and more likely to commit crimes”. Other topics that also showed “negative trends” are “health issues” and “United States politics”, with topics such as “lifestyle” or “leisure” “tending towards more positive feelings”. With regard to another theme associated with news about depression, that of the “global recession”, the focus is the “economic difficulties caused by the spread of covid-19 in different sectors”, presenting “a more contradictory positive feeling”. In other words, “the structure of the reports initially described the economic challenges, to then emphasize the initiatives to facilitate recovery in response to the crisis”. Thus, the authors note that “a significant change in general sentiment was observed”, as “until January 2021, the continuous decrease in the amount of positive news was interrupted”, and that afterwards “the aggregate number of positive news exceeded that of negative news almost every month, signaling a general change from a negative feeling to a more positive feeling in relation to the economic circumstances discussed”. The authors consider that the change may be due “to the fact that people have been forced to adapt to a ‘new normal’ and begin the recovery of the economy, health, and society after a year of living with the pandemic”. Regarding the theme of US politics found in news associated with depression, the texts “emphasized rivalry and the presidential electoral process, as well as politicians from different parties who experienced depression”. Few institutional responses The study also looked at so-called coping strategies, that is, cognitive or behavioral efforts used to deal with less good situations. And here, the news analyzed focused mainly on “information about skills and resources” available to help people with depression, such as “support lines for suicidal intentions and suicide prevention”. Mental health programs provided by local organizations were also presented, such as Mind HK, the Kely Support Group and the Mental Health Association of Hong Kong, and articles were written about “counseling services and therapies for people with depression”, or even physical exercise recommendations. The authors highlight that, when analyzing the news, they noticed “the insufficiency of political interventions, institutional support and financial assistance for individuals with depression, which indicates a deficiency at the societal level of coping strategies and which are present in journalistic coverage”.

item.title: Diocese of Macau/450 years | New Catholic Center will have a hotel
item.description: The new Catholic Center should open “in the middle of the second quarter” of this year and will have a hotel, prepared to receive “pilgrims and tourists”, says the Diocese of Macau. At a time when the institution celebrates 450 years, the inauguration of the Catholic Center is based on “the vision” of D. Paulo José Tavares, bishop of Macau in the 60s and 70s After many years of emptiness and construction work on the corner of Avenida da Praia Grande and Rua do Campo, the new Catholic Center is preparing to open its doors later this year and is perhaps the most important event in the celebration of the 450th anniversary of the Diocese of Macau. HM asked questions to the Diocese of Macau regarding the reopening of the building, which confirmed that the official opening is scheduled “for the second quarter” of this year. This building, with a total of 17 floors, will have features designed for religious purposes, but also a hotel prepared to receive all types of people. "The Catholic Center will be a nerve center for disseminating and sharing the mission of the Catholic Church. The lower floors will feature a chapel, an auditorium, conference rooms, exhibition areas and spaces for activities." While “the upper floors will function as a hotel, offering welcoming and comfortable accommodation, imbued with a spirit of service”. In the diocese's written response, it is added that the hotel facilities “were designed to receive both pilgrims and tourists, welcoming Catholics and non-Catholics with hospitality and inclusion”. It is worth remembering that in December employees began to be recruited for the hotel unit, in partnership with the Directorate of Services for Labor Affairs (DSAL). In a job matching session aimed at residents, held on December 5th, with the “Companhia de Gestão do Centro Católico”, 23 job openings were made available for sales manager, assistant reception manager, chef, head of security, room service supervisor and acquisition supervisor, reads the DSAL note released in November. The Diocese of Macau did not want to tell HM how much it would cost to rebuild the new Catholic Center, saying only that initial forecasts had slipped due to the pandemic. "The Catholic Center is currently undergoing development and submission and approval by the Government. Following the challenges of the Covid-19 pandemic, construction costs have increased significantly. We are grateful for the understanding and support of the builders and contractors, which allowed the reconstruction project to be completed successfully. At the same time, we warmly welcome donations from all sectors of society to help sustain and carry forward the Catholic Center's original mission of serving the Macau community." A bishop still present Asked about the main goals of the new Catholic Center, the Diocese of Macau describes that the building “aims to continue the spiritual mission of the Catholic Church and incorporate the spirit of Christ”, influenced by the work of Bishop D. Paulo José Tavares, who carried out his mission in Macau in the mid-20th century. Of particular note is the fact that D. Paulo José Tavares, who died in 1973 and was appointed Bishop of Macau in 1961, was important in maintaining the presence of the Catholic Church in Macau at the time of the “1,2,3” movement. Between November 1966 and February 1967, the Cultural Revolution manifested itself in the territory, bringing together many local students, who intended to change the content of Catholic education. D. Paulo José Tavares fought with these groups of protesters, managing to keep teaching in Catholic schools and the spirit associated with them unchanged. In this way, and based on “the vision” of this bishop, the diocese intends for the new Catholic Center to “continue to serve as a vital bridge for the Macau community, promoting dialogue, exchange and integration of faith and culture”. It is also the intention to “open the doors [of the Center] to visitors from all over the world, reinforcing not only its role as a spiritual refuge, but also infusing new vitality into the religious and cultural panorama of Macau”. António Pedro Costa, author of the cleric's biography, entitled “D. Paulo José Tavares – The diplomat bishop”, described, in an interview with HM in 2023, that the bishop “was a breath of fresh air”, and a figure cherished by the Chinese community at the time. "These attitudes of valuing the Chinese community led to a rapprochement and the establishment of a relationship of trust. Only in this way was he able to take his objectives forward, as he realized that he had to have the population on his side. But this caused him a lot of trouble with the European clergy, who did not agree with D. Paulo José Tavares' stance. It meant that the population saw him as an ally and not a person who comes from outside and imposes his ideas", said the author. A year of celebrations It was in 1576, in the fourth year of the Wanli reign, of the Ming Dynasty, that the Diocese was founded in Macau, with January 23rd being the official date of celebration. However, the next few months will also be festive. In a previously released statement, the Diocese of Macau states that it has had, over the years, “the mission of establishing bridges between East and West, promoting education, charity and pastoral service”, leaving “a deep and lasting mark on the cultural, educational and religious development of Macau”. The theme of the celebrations is “From Macau to the World: 450 years of Mission and Mercy”. The new Catholic Center will host two thematic exhibitions, entitled “Honoring the Past, Creating the Future” and “Witness to Heritage, Mission in the World”. These exhibitions aim to “reflect the development of the Diocese from historical, personal and cultural perspectives, as well as its future directions”, highlights the same note. Tomorrow a sacred music concert will take place at the Sé Church with eight choral groups from Macau, Hong Kong and the Province of Guangzhou, with the sounds of the church's new pipe organ being heard. From 7:30 pm onwards, the Diocesan Choir of Macau, the Cathedral Schola ensemble and other choral groups from Macau will perform, such as Coro Perosi, Dolce Voce and Cantate Chorus, without forgetting other ensembles from Hong Kong and Guangzhou. The Diocese highlights that the “most symbolic and large-scale initiative of the commemorative year” will be the “great celebration” scheduled for October 31st this year, which consists of a reception and mass. “Through this solemn celebration, the Diocese will give thanks to God for the graces and mission granted over four and a half centuries, and will pray that He continues to guide the way forward”, the same statement describes. There will also be initiatives carried out by “various diocesan institutions” in the coming months, namely “cultural shows, school competitions, academic symposiums, social activities, youth meetings, online training resources, parish initiatives and liturgical celebrations”. “Through transversal and intergenerational participation, the commemorative year seeks to deepen public knowledge about the historical development of the Diocese and its service to the community, promoting the spirit of the diocesan motto ‘Scientia et Virtus’ (Science and Virtue), which inspires a practice of service based on the balance between knowledge and ethical care.” At a time when it celebrates 450 years of existence, the Diocese says it wants to chart the future, “walking with the residents of Macau in reflecting on the past and continuing its mission of faith, service and culture in this new stage”.

item.title: Higher education | Academic highlights growth of the sector in Macau
item.description: In “Macau, networks, dialogues and affections – The consolidation of the Portuguese-speaking community of China studies”, academic Pedro Steenhagen argues that Macau is taking great strides to be a bridge at an academic level with Portuguese-speaking countries, despite “still having a long way to go to achieve its goals” The article “Macau, networks, dialogues and affections – The consolidation of the Portuguese-speaking community of China studies”, written by academic and doctoral student Pedro Steenhagen, has just been published in Revista Sinóptica, an editorial project of the Observa China portal. The article highlights the role that the Macao SAR can play in connecting its higher education system with Portuguese-speaking countries, and the growing importance it has had in this area. “The aforementioned efforts in the field of education are not just rhetorical”, he described in the article, noting that “in relatively few decades, the Asian nation has become a true power in the area”. Pedro Steenhagen is based on two world rankings to assess the quality of higher education in the world, namely the World University Rankings 2026 by Times Higher Education (from 2025), which shows how “Macau, a small special administrative region in China, has three ranked universities: University of Macau (145), University of Science and Technology of Macau (251-300) and University of the City of Macau (601-800)”, these data being related to positions occupied in the ranking. “Very interestingly, MSAR universities have experienced tremendous growth; for example, the University of Macau has seen a jump of more than 250 positions in the ranking in the last 10 years”, highlights the author of the article. In his view, these data translate into the fact that Macao SAR “assumes an increasingly relevant leadership role in the area of ​​education and research”.
