Furthermore, it has “the best university in the Portuguese-speaking world in its territory, is experiencing an intense expansion of the education and research sector and serves as a fundamental axis for the exchange of people and the promotion of knowledge”. Taking the rankings into account, Pedro Steenhagen's article recalls that China “has five [universities] in the top 50 in the world: Tsinghua University (12), Beijing University (13), Fudan University (36), Zhejiang University (39) and Shanghai Jiaotong University (40)”, with the Times Higher Education ranking “showing a total of 97 results for mainland China”. Brazil, as “the largest Portuguese-speaking country on the globe, has a total of 59 results, and its five best universities are: University of São Paulo (201-250), State University of Campinas (351-400), Federal University of Rio de Janeiro (601-800), Universidade Estadual Paulista (601-800) and Federal University of Rio Grande do Sul (601-800)”. In the case of Portugal, there are 16 results, with the five best higher education establishments being the University of Coimbra, University of Lisbon, University of Porto, Universidade Nova de Lisboa and ISCTE-Instituto Universitário de Lisboa. Looking at the remaining Portuguese-speaking countries, Pedro Steenhagen highlights how “Mozambique has only one presence in the ranking”, with Eduardo Mondlane University, while “no other Portuguese-speaking country has ranked universities”. A long way Despite the good results, Pedro Steenhagen points out that “the Macao SAR still has a long way to go to achieve all its goals”. However, “its enormous potential as a regional and global protagonist in areas such as technology and innovation, sustainable tourism, creative industry, finance and, particularly, teaching, research and people exchange is already quite clear”. The academic article refers to the “Lusophony component and the unique connection with the PLPs [Portuguese-speaking countries] which adds even more dynamism to its ambitions and to a trajectory that can already be considered incredibly successful since its retrocession”, that is, the transition of the Portuguese administration of Macau to China, in 1999. In the case of the University of Macau (UM), the first to emerge in Macau, and which is now celebrating 45 years of existence, “it has the largest Portuguese department in Asia”, it is highlighted in the article, in addition to having “two research centers: the Research Center for Portuguese-Asian Studies and the Chinese-Portuguese Bilingual Teaching and Training Center”, with “its growing internationalization movement being notable”. Pedro Steenhagen counts the “student exchange programs with more than 10 Brazilian universities”, in addition to the strengthening of “collaboration in teaching and research via international alliances, such as the Association of Portuguese Language Universities, and the establishment of the Center for Judicial and Legal Studies of China and Portuguese-speaking Countries”. The example of the City University of Macau (UCM) is mentioned, where the Institute for Research on Portuguese-Speaking Countries is established, with “unique programs” of master's and doctoral degrees in Studies of Portuguese-Speaking Countries. By establishing partnerships with ISCTE-IUL, UCM is in a “position at the forefront of academic programs and initiatives that go beyond purely linguistic and cultural issues” in connection with Portuguese-speaking countries. There is also the example of a private higher education institution, the University of São José, which “signed [agreements], for example, with the Federal University of Ceará and the Portuguese Catholic University, not only to bring closer relations on a bilateral basis, but also to promote joint projects”. The place of the Government Pedro Steenhagen also refers to the intervention of the Macao SAR Government in connecting with the Portuguese-speaking world, namely the Directorate of Economic and Technological Development Services and the Macau Business Incubation Center for Young People, which have held the Macau Innovation and Entrepreneurship Competition for Technology Companies from Brazil and Portugal since 2021. Of note is the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center (CCCM) in Lisbon and the Macau Houses spread around the world which, “together with international initiatives such as the Meeting of Macanese Communities, contribute not only to the vitality of intellectual exchanges, but also to the cultivation of memory and affective ties between Macau, the diaspora, descendants and Portuguese-speaking communities”. “Associations such as the Association of Brazilian Studies in Macau and the Industrial and Commercial Association of Macau offer substance, in a complementary way to universities and research institutes, for strengthening relationships, developing networks and generating increasingly fruitful dialogues between the parties involved”, it further reads. Pedro Steenhagen is a doctoral candidate in the field of International Politics at the School of International Relations and Public Affairs at Fudan University, and president of the Brazilian Citizens' Council in Shanghai. On the Observa China platform, he is development director and coordinator of the China-Brazil and Lusofonia Relations Center. The platform is a think-tank created in 2020 by “a group of young professionals and students with the mission of creating a network to qualify the debate on China in Portuguese”, reads the website.

item.title: Book | Changes in Portuguese colonial policy at the end of the 19th century
item.description: Defended in 2018, the doctoral thesis by Célia Reis, professor and researcher in contemporary History, has just been published in a book by the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center with the support of the Macau Foundation. “The Power between Lisbon and the East – Persistences and Changes in Administration. From the Ultimatum to the Colonial Act” circulates between Macau, India and Timor and brings “a good contribution to the history of colonial power” Célia Reis, professor and researcher in the area of ​​Contemporary History at Universidade Nova de Lisboa, has just published her doctoral thesis in a book focused on Portuguese colonial power in the East from the end of the 19th century. “Power between Lisbon and the East – Persistences and Changes in Administration. From the Ultimatum to the Colonial Act” is an edition of the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center (CCCM), supported by the Macau Foundation (FM), and arises from the thesis defended in 2018. To HM, Célia Reis argued that this book and its research bring “a good contribution to the history of colonial power”, focusing “on the administrative configurations in the colonies of the East, India, Macau and Timor, in the period between the Ultimatum and the Colonial Act”, published in 1930. “Thousands of documents” were analyzed, namely “formal letters, private letters, reports from departments, drafts, small notes” that demonstrate decisions and the functioning of the Administration in the territories of Portuguese India, Macau and Timor. We speak, according to the author, of “a time of many experiments, in different phases”, and, for Célia Reis, “a gap that existed in Portuguese historiography” was overcome in the sense of a better understanding of the functioning of Portuguese colonial power in these years, and specifically in the territories to the East. In the case of Macau, the book and study contribute “to an administrative history of the period in question”, namely “why it was decided, how it was decided; what problems were posed at an administrative level; how the power of Lisbon was felt and how it was resolved, or how it sought to influence the central power; or who represented it”. The territory is also placed “alongside two other spaces, India and Timor, which are very different, enabling a comparative history, an emphasis on what was common or specific, which, without a doubt, is essential for deeper knowledge”. Célia Reis says she is “very happy with the publication”, for being able to “share the work, investigations and their results, with the public, helping to better understand the history and lived realities”. Historical adjustments The years dedicated to this research show many changes in colonial policy, taking into account that “the colonization movement seen from the last decades of the 19th century was reflected in the way of governing the colonies, giving rise to discussions, studies and adaptations to realities”. Célia Reis further explained that “the existing framework, which had been institutionalized since 1869, was being altered by the creation of new departments, the introduction of new forms of financial control or the change in the status and organization of some colonies, making the administration less homogeneous than was seen in many speeches”. At issue is, in particular, a decree dated December 1, 1869, which proved to be the “true organic charter of the Overseas Provinces”, as stated in the conclusion of the work, without forgetting the Administrative Code of 1842, which “shaped the overseas political bodies for decades”. “Although they lead to a continuous model, in the bodies and their functions, they did not prevent the progressive organization of new configurations or the adaptation of different structures”, we also read. The researcher highlights the occurrence of successive attempts at modernization in legislative and administrative terms, even before the implementation of the First Republic. “Several proposals for modifications were made, with a more modernizing intention, and which had greater emphasis from the last years of the Monarchy, continuing later through the Republic for a more structured change, which ended up being carried out by laws published in 1914 and 1920”. From October 5, 1910, when the Monarchy fell and a republican regime was established, there was “a ministerial change, with the assumption of reference to colonies replacing Ultramar and the autonomy of its ministry”. "In overseas areas, the change of regime was understood as an opportunity for administrative renewal, as can be understood by India's proposal, or by the openness expressed by government bodies to changes in Macau. But the new republican regime remained, in the field of colonial administration, trapped in the circumstances of its beginning, by constitutionalizing it. In fact, in the wide range of changes, colonial issues constituted only one part and parliamentarians did not dedicate themselves sufficiently to them, despite the existence of proposals”, reads the conclusion of the work. In the years of Republicanism, there was “political processing that imposed a framework of parliamentarism, due to some distrust towards the Executive”, and at the level of the colonies “this option led to greater interference by the Senate in the appointment of governors, moving away from what were considered more effective models”. Furthermore, “the rupture also did not take place in the field of participation in Congress, where overseas territories maintained their space in the political game”. "The republican decision also showed a conservative nature in relation to municipal bodies. As it was not possible to carry out a more in-depth study here, it was found that the political vision based on the importance of the municipality, as a space for participation, prevented the deeper changes that were proposed for the internal organization", is mentioned in the conclusion. Barriers and control “Obstacles occurred, such as Sidonism”, followed, with attempts at change being found to be “insufficient”. It should be noted that Sidonism had its origins in a military coup carried out by Sidónio Pais against the republican regime in force in those years, since 1910, and which operated between 1917 and 1918. It was an authoritarian and militaristic regime. According to Célia Reis, it was after the Military Dictatorship of 1926 that “we moved towards greater control” in terms of colonial policy. In general terms, “the regime that began on October 5th was, in short, modernizing in some sense, but its political conceptions and the insertion of colonial issues in the broader space of changes to be carried out in the country allowed the persistence of many previous modes”. “Despite these limitations, the 1914 laws undoubtedly constituted a modernizing step, replacing the existing framework”, concluded Célia Reis, referring to the years of Sidonism as “a rupture in the path that was being followed, with the retreat of colonial capabilities, particularly collegiate bodies and local participation, as well as a decrease in financial autonomy”. This “political trend” experienced in the then metropolis ended up “transplanted overseas”. In terms of documentation used in this investigation, we have the example of the Organic Charters, implemented by Portugal for each colony, and which “arose following the laws of 1914”, analyzing “the various proposals existing in India, Macau and Timor, their implementation process, the essential characteristics of those that belonged to those colonies and their subsequent trajectory”. According to the investigation, “they were the product of the moment in which they took place, inserted in a broader change introduced in Portugal by the Republic, which conditioned their existence, firstly due to the different contributions they had and, later, due to the lack of definition of their situation”. This study analyzes “the way in which central and colonial decisions were operationalized”, having considered “governmental and parliamentary structures”. In the case of colonies, “their organs of power” were studied, where “the governor, interlocutor between metropolis and colony, acted, examining his capabilities and possibility of action, when he was under the authority of a distant ministry, but alongside other supervisory powers, particularly financial, Councils and, in general, under pressure from the various forces of the colony”. In the case of the “competences and composition of the various Councils and means of financial control” they have experienced, in these years, “a change, much more pronounced throughout the various reforms; mainly integrating civil servants”. Furthermore, “the combination of other elements of local society proved to be different, depending on the colonies”. Lisbon Orders Célia Reis describes that “local deliberations were dependent on superior sanction and remained so beyond the reforms”, and “the practice often circumvented the norm, maintaining uncertainty as a form of action”. Another point to highlight in this study is how the fact that Lisbon made the most important decisions affected life in the colonies. "Although the mandatory sanction remained, the legislation introduced changes, mainly based on the establishment of deadlines. Nevertheless, the metropolitan decision-making capacity remained essential, affecting the life of the colonies. The forms used, persisting what existed or changing the framework, essentially constituted adaptations to the circumstances that occurred, responding both to foreign models and to the needs imposed on Portuguese realities. Politics, in its instability and phases of change, also determined this path", he said.

item.title: University of Macau | Former teachers recall experiences
item.description: The University of Macau celebrates 45 years and HM invited two former professors to recall their professional experiences at the institution. Brian Hall, from the field of psychology, found “the ideal environment” to start his career. Vera Lúcia Raposo says she “learned a lot” and saw Law as a “meeting place” A series of events begins this Sunday to celebrate the 45 years of existence of the University of Macau (UM), including the “Open Day” which takes place at the Lakeside Theater between 11am and 5pm (see secondary text). It was in March 1981, still under the name of the University of East Asia, that UM began to take its first steps in local higher education, namely in the teaching of Law in the Portuguese language. It was the first time that Macau had its own university, providing a higher education offering for residents, who no longer only had the opportunity to pursue studies abroad, such as Portugal, the United Kingdom, Hong Kong or Australia. To commemorate the anniversary, HM invited two former professors of the institution, from two different academic areas, to talk about their experience at UM. Vera Lúcia Raposo, who taught at the Faculty of Law from January 2014, remembers feeling “a shock”. "The classes were entirely in English, and I had never taught a complete course in that language, the pressure to publish in indexed journals was absolute and the evaluation system was periodic, demanding and relentless. Nothing there resembled the regime I was used to, where the simple passage of time often seemed to guarantee the natural advancement of an academic career", she said. However, adaptation arrived and ended up following “the rules” to this day, namely at NOVA School of Law. “At the time, however, these requirements were still profoundly strange in Portugal, and they continue to be so, in many contexts, even today”, he says. Vera Lúcia Raposo says she “learned a lot” at UM, as “the demanding scientific production goals and interdisciplinary research contributed to defining the type of academic I am today”. “I owe UM more than a professional transition, but a transformation”, he assures. A cultural melting pot The former professor at the UM Faculty of Law also remembers arriving in a territory that was “a space of true cultural amalgamation”, with the institution being an example of this. "Working side by side with colleagues of different nationalities and cultures was a rare privilege. In particular, the intellectual coexistence between Chinese, Macanese and Portuguese colleagues, in the study and teaching of Macau Law, offered me an absolutely unique way of thinking about Law: less self-centered, more dialoguing, more aware of its cultural and historical contingency", highlighted Vera Lúcia Raposo. Brian Hall, who taught at the Faculty of Social Sciences and coordinated the “Global and Community Mental Health Research Group”, highlights the possibility of doing pioneering work in the area of ​​mental health. "UM gave me the opportunity to develop unique and never-before-taught courses in Global Mental Health and Global Health. They were the first courses of their kind in Macau and at the university", recalled Brian Hall, who is now linked to New York University Shanghai. “I was grateful to have some really great students who were interested in topics like migration, global and digital mental health, and I really enjoyed mentoring them in and out of the classroom.” The first prizes The academic also highlights the fact that he “regularly published research articles with undergraduate and postgraduate students, taking them to international research conferences, where they won awards”. “We were among the first at the university to achieve these excellent results and I am eternally grateful to UM for providing me with all these opportunities”, he confessed. Brian Hall also added that he joined UM “in a period of ambitious transition and growth to become a research university”, providing “an ideal environment to launch a career”. When he was at UM, Brian Hall received, in 2020, an award for his work, the “Excellence in Advising Award” from the Center for Global Health at Johns Hopkins University, from the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health. "The university rewarded me for my excellent research performance by granting me permission to apply for an early promotion to associate professor, which I was granted just four years after joining the university. UM served as a springboard to build a regional and international career," he said. Book of Genesis The need to create a university in Macau arose from the desire to develop the territory, especially taking into account the signing of the Joint Declaration between Portugal and China in 1987. The former Governor of Macau Garcia Leandro recalled the first moments of the creation of the future university in the book “Macau in the Years of the Portuguese Revolution 1974-1979”, which reads that the initial budget was 40 million patacas for construction “on land on the island of Taipa, with a modern architectural project”. The institution should have capacity for “a population of two thousand students in four years, at a rate of 500 per year”, with “the leadership of the various course chairs guaranteed by a dean professor with a doctorate from the University of Oxford and by several university professors from Matteo Ricci, the Chinese University of Hong Kong and also from the USA”, it is described. The first contract to train the teaching team and pedagogical content was signed in February 1979 with the Matteo Ricci group. “I believe it was another good service provided to the population”, wrote the former Governor. In 1991, the institution changed its name to what it currently has. According to data from the 2024 annual report, the latest available, UM has 52,146 graduated students, and in the first semester of the 2024/2025 academic year, 15,147 students attended the university, from all educational levels. Highlight is the greater number of students from abroad, 9,328, compared to 5,819 local students. Open day in Hengqin Despite having been formally created in March, UM begins to celebrate 45 years of existence this Sunday with an Open Day. According to a statement from the educational institution, between 11am and 5pm the public will be able to visit the Lakeside Theater, where the first ceremony takes place, and then other areas of the campus in Hengqin, namely the main campus and the UM Scientific and Technological Research Institute in Zhuhai, in the Youth Entrepreneurship Valley in Hengqin. This route also includes the possibility of visiting, for the first time, the Transitional Research and Education Site at Yuxin Tower, in the Cooperation Zone. “Through a wide range of on-site activities and live online broadcasts, the event will showcase UM’s latest developments and achievements in teaching, research and community service”, highlights the same note, which recalls how UM was the first higher education institution in Macau to “extend teaching and research activities to the Guangdong-Macao Deep Cooperation Zone in Hengqin”. On that day there will also be “approximately 250 activities on the main campus throughout the day, including admissions lectures, academic and research activities and interactive games”. "Visitors interested in academic subjects can attend engaging lectures on science and other disciplines, while sports enthusiasts can explore UM's sports facilities. Families can also participate in interactive games at stands, scientific experiments, workshops and knowledge challenges organized by various faculties, residences and laboratories", it is revealed. On Open Day there will also be discounts in the restaurant area.

item.title: Patriotism | Sam Hou Fai emphasizes priority to national interests
item.description: “We always put the safeguarding of sovereignty, security and national development interests first, resolutely implementing the principle of ‘Macau governed by patriots’”, stated the Chief Executive in a speech given yesterday at the reception of the Spring party hosted by the Liaison Office of the Central People's Government in the Macao SAR. Sam Hou Fai summarized last year's political action, with particular emphasis on national integration and defense of state security. "Within the scope of safeguarding national security, we took decisive measures, handling cases in accordance with the law, in order to resolutely prevent and prevent infiltration and interference by external forces. This ensured the effective maintenance of stability and harmony in Macau", said the local politician. The leader of the Executive mentioned Xi Jinping's instructions several times, namely the phrase, which has “always present”, “Prosperity should not induce complacency, nor does security justify forgetting danger”. Stating that 2026 is a crucial year for alignment with national strategies, Sam Hou Fai reinforced the promise to maintain stability. “We will continue to implement the principle of ‘one country, two systems’ in a comprehensive, precise and resolute manner, firmly safeguarding national sovereignty, security and development interests and resolutely upholding the insurmountable line that ‘there can be no chaos in Macau’.”

item.title: Borders | Goods now have a single customs declaration
item.description: A service that allows the delivery of just one customs declaration for the passage of goods between Guangdong and Macau went into operation yesterday, on an experimental basis, the Directorate of Economic and Technological Development Services (DSEDT) said yesterday. Therefore, companies only need to fill in the declaration data once and the information will be shared between the authorities in Mainland China and Macau. DSEDT states that the measure aims to improve “the level of facilitation of cross-border trade, better serving economic development and better meeting the needs of society”. The Macao SAR services department adds that the so-called “single window” for goods from Guangdong and Macau aims to provide facilitated customs clearance services through digitalized and computerized means to companies exporting from Mainland China and importing from Macau, shortening the time spent on customs declaration. The Government also indicates that the new service helps to reduce labor costs and time, without the need to repeat data entry, as well as to reduce errors and increase efficiency.

item.title: Presidential | Portuguese choose President over the weekend
item.description: Tomorrow and Sunday, Portuguese people residing in Macau will be able to vote in the Consultado-Geral to choose the next President of the Portuguese Republic. The polls will be open on both days, from 8am to 7pm, after three days of early voting in which 78 voters participated, more than triple the number of those in the first round The Portuguese will once again be called upon to vote in the second round of elections to elect the next President of the Republic, in a vote contested between candidates from the Socialist Party (António José Seguro) and Chega (André Ventura). In the Macao SAR, Portuguese people will be able to vote on Saturday and Sunday, from 8am to 7pm, at the Consulate General of Portugal in Macau and Hong Kong, just like voters who will vote abroad in the various diplomatic missions around the world. Remember that only national citizens who are registered abroad will be able to vote. To choose the next President of the Republic, voters must present a citizen card, identity card, or document that has an up-to-date photograph and is usually used for identification (passport or driving license). On the 27th, 28th and 29th of January, the consulate general received voters who voted in advance. This modality of suffrage was open to voters due to "the exercise of public or private functions, representing a national team. In addition, students, researchers, teachers and research fellows at a higher education institution, patients undergoing treatment, or voters accompanying the aforementioned citizens were able to vote in advance. According to information revealed by the Consulate General of Portugal in Macau and Hong Kong to HM, 78 voters voted in advance in the second round, more than triple the number of early votes in the first round, when 25 early votes were counted. Local vs National In the first round, the votes counted in Macau gave an advantage to the PSD candidate, Luís Marques Mendes, with 47.19 percent of the votes, followed by the socialist António José Seguro (20.98 percent) and André Ventura with 12.4 percent. At national level, António José Seguro won the first round with 1,755,563 votes (31.11 percent), followed by André Ventura, with 1,327,021 votes (23.52 percent) and João Cotrim Figueiredo, with 903,057 votes (16 percent). Luís Marques Mendes ended up in fifth place, out of the second round with 637,442 votes (11.3 percent).

item.title: National Security | Lawyers excluded with no chance of appealing
item.description: Processes classified as national security will cover criminal cases, but can also extend to administrative and civil areas. Lawyers will be required to present information about households, such as nationality and foreign political connections Lawyers who are excluded from trials related to national security by the Macao SAR State Security Defense Commission (CDSE) are prevented from filing an appeal to challenge the decision. The information is contained in the Government's proposal published yesterday on the Legislative Assembly portal and which deprives defendants of the possibility of freely choosing any lawyer registered with the Macau Lawyers Association. According to the procedures defined in the bill, the State Security Defense Commission will choose the lawyer for the defendants “in judicial proceedings of any nature in which the competent authority has well-founded reasons to believe that there is a need to protect the interests of State security”. According to this formulation, the exclusion of a lawyer may occur in criminal proceedings, such as the one currently underway against former deputy Au Kam San, but also in administrative or even private law proceedings, if it is considered that in some way “there is a need to protect the interests of State security”. Within the scope of the ongoing process, even before being chosen as representative, the lawyer must go to court and inform the judge of his desire to be appointed as a representative of one of the parties involved. From this moment on, an analysis of the lawyer and his family begins, which may require the obligation to present elements such as the lawyer's own nationality, members of his family and connections with organizations or individuals abroad, among “others”. This formulation thus opens the door for family members to have to declare their affiliation with political parties outside Macau. However, the required elements are not specified in the proposed law. If the judge considers that the elements provided by the lawyers initially are not sufficient, he may also require the presentation of “other information that he considers essential for verification”. The Boss decides Once the information has been collected, the CDSE decides whether it considers that the lawyer corresponds to the will of the political power for the specific case, issuing an opinion granting or refusing the “special authorization to the judicial representative”. The criteria that will be adopted by the Chief Executive, the secretaries, advisors to the Central Government, who do not vote, and other members of the Government linked to the police and other entities were not revealed. However, the law eliminates the possibility of judicial appeal or challenge within the commission itself. The Government's proposal thus adopts the policy of the electoral law for deputies, with the difference that the removal of a lawyer from a specific case does not prevent him from practicing the profession, nor from submitting new requests in the future, without being “frozen” for five years. Contrary to what happens with judges, the diploma does not exclude the participation of Portuguese lawyers in processes of this nature. Outside the control of the courts The law also defines the powers of the CDSE, which will have the power to issue orders to all public entities involved with the objectives of defending the security of the State, ensuring the prosperity and stability of the Macao SAR and guaranteeing the legitimate rights and interests of the residents of the Macao SAR and other people in the SAR. The diploma also confirms the CDSE's competence to issue binding opinions in relation to the elections for the Chief Executive and the Legislative Assembly. However, the law brings something new: the principle that the authorities' decisions follow the CDSE's opinions, not accepting challenges or legal action, unless there is a legal norm providing for this appeal. The Sam Hou Fai Government's proposal also defines that the commission's work “is free from any interference from other entities or individuals in the Macao SAR”, with no public information about the commission or its work being made available. Within the scope of the principle of secrecy, the commission can also hire the workers it deems necessary, and carry out expenses without the need for disclosure. The accounts will only be analyzed by the Chief Executive, who also presides over the CDSE. Ongoing process The Government's proposal for the new CDSE law is justified in the documents sent to the Legislative Assembly with the need to improve the “legal system and reinforce the top structure of the State security defense system”, to “firmly safeguard the sovereignty, security and development interests of the State, build a solid barrier to defend the State's security and maintain the general stability of society”. The Executive also indicates that the changes aim to “effectively prevent and repress external interference and ensure that the State’s security interests are not harmed”. The proposed law enters the hemicycle at a time when the investigation into former deputy Au Kam San is expected to be concluded, the only case made public in the Macao SAR related to national security. Arrested in July last year, the Democrat has been in pre-trial detention ever since. If the law is approved before a possible trial, the process may follow the stipulations of the diploma.

item.title: Hengqin New District | Residents can now buy two apartments
item.description: From now on, Macau residents will be able to buy two apartments in the New Macau District in Henqgin. The decision was announced by the Executive Committee of the Deep Cooperation Zone, which justified the measure with the “optimization of the housing stock” Political authorities in the Guangdong-Macao In-depth Cooperation Zone in Hengqin have once again eased restrictions on the purchase of apartments in Macau's New District on Mountain Island. This time, the Executive Committee of the Deep Cooperation Zone announced that Macao SAR residents can purchase two apartments in the housing complex built for the population of Macau. The measure was presented as a way to “implement the spirit of directives from the national and provincial authorities of Guangdong to optimize the existing housing stock, adjust housing purchase restriction policies” and “effectively expand quality living space for Macau residents”. The executive committee also adds that the possibility of purchasing two apartments aims to “respond to public concerns”. Furthermore, it is indicated that if problems occur in implementing the measure, the Hengqin Urban Planning and Construction Services Bureau is the entity that should be contacted directly. The executive committee also cites the “current development of the cooperation zone” and the “response to demands from the business sector” as reasons for changing the restrictions on purchasing housing in the New Neighborhood of Macau. Fewer barriers Last September, Macau Urban Renewal announced the start of sales of units in Tower 11 of the housing complex, with special discounted prices for parking spaces, renovation works and the purchase of electrical appliances. Since sales of units in the housing complex began, several restrictions on transactions have been lifted. Criteria have been adjusted, including removing the age limit, allowing minors to own property, removing the restriction on resale within five years of purchase, and adjusting the limit on purchasing residential units. Furthermore, in mid-2024, in the midst of the real estate crisis, the initial concept of the New Macau Neighborhood in Hengqin was changed to increase occupancy. Instead of purchases by residents of the Macao SAR, the authorities of the cooperation zone began to allow rental of units to students from Mainland China, as well as employees of the University of Macau, the Hengqin School Annex to the Hou Kong School and the Medical Post of the New Neighborhood of Macau. The New Neighborhood of Macau is made up of 27 residential towers, with approximately 4,000 housing units.

item.title: Chief of Executive highlights contributions from the City University of Macau
item.description: The Chief Executive, Sam Hou Fai, met this Tuesday with Chan Meng Kam, businessman, former deputy and also chancellor and president of the Board of Directors of the City University of Macau (UCM). The meeting served to discuss “the development of higher education in Macau and the training of qualified staff”, with the Chief Executive highlighting that, at a time when UCM celebrates 45 years of existence, “it has actively responded to the guidelines and directives of the Country and the MSAR in the field of higher education, having achieved widely recognized results in improving the quality of education, training qualified staff, scientific innovation and service to society”. Sam Hou Fai also understands that the higher education institution “is aligned with the development strategy of adequate diversification ‘1+4′”, having achieved “significant results in boosting interdisciplinary development and building an international and comprehensive institution”. Plan the future In the meeting with Chan Meng Kam, the highest ruler of the Macao SAR did not neglect the advice. The UCM must “adapt to the needs of the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area in terms of industrial development and qualified staff, optimize curricula in emerging disciplines, such as artificial intelligence, Big Health, finance and technology”, in addition to “promoting the transformation of scientific research results and their application”. The UCM was also asked to “train more high-quality qualified staff with practical knowledge”, in addition to “continuing to expand international exchange channels”. Sam Hou Fai's statements appear in an official note that does not contain testimonies from Chan Meng Kam.

item.title: Meeting | Sam Hou Fai debated foreign policy with Bian Lixin
item.description: The new commissioner of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs promised that she will contribute to the construction of “a strong national security barrier” in Macau The Chief Executive, Sam Hou Fai, and the new commissioner of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MNE) in Macau, Bian Lixin, met on Tuesday to discuss Macau's foreign policy issues. The meeting took place behind closed doors and was announced in a press release by the Social Communication Office. During the meeting, Sam Hou Fai stated that the Government “is determined to leverage Macau’s position as ‘a center, a platform and a base’” and “fully utilize its advantages in connecting domestic and international markets and fusing Chinese and Western cultures”. In this sense, the leader indicated that he will “actively promote the strategy of ‘expanding abroad and attracting investment’ and constantly increase its competitiveness and international influence”. Sam Hou Fai told Bian that “visits abroad are being planned for this year and there are plans to establish an economic and commercial delegation in Southeast Asian countries, with the aim of further expanding the tourist market and consolidating Macau’s position as a global tourism and leisure center”. One of these visits should include trips to Portugal and Spain, which were initially scheduled for the 16th to 23rd of September, but ended up being postponed. Thanks to MNE At the meeting, Sam Hou Fai thanked the MNE for the “strong support to the territory, helping the Macao SAR to respond to various internal and external challenges”, which were not indicated. The highest leader of the Macao SAR also pointed out that over the years the MNE has supported Macau “in valuing its unique advantages”, “in expanding exchange and cooperation with the outside world”, “in expanding external contacts” and “in strengthening its capabilities for governing external relations”. Sam Hou Fai also highlighted the “full protection of the rights and interests of Macau residents abroad” by the MNE and the “impetus for the development of adequate diversification of the economy”. This was the first publicized meeting between Sam and Bian Lixin, the new MNE commissioner who arrived in Macau at the end of January to succeed Liu Xianfa. Principles and barriers In turn, according to the version of the meeting of the MNE Commissioner in Macau, Bian Lixin highlighted that she felt “deeply honored” to have been appointed the eighth Commissioner of the MNE in Macau. Bian also highlighted “the tremendous developments achieved by Macau at an economic and social level in the last 26 years”, which in his opinion demonstrate “the institutional advantages and strong vitality of the ‘one country, two systems’ principle”. At the same time, the new person in charge assured that the commissioner will implement “with determination the important decisions and plans of the Central Government regarding external relations and work related to Macau” and that “it will firmly build a strong national security barrier” and “will deeply practice the concepts of ‘diplomacy for the benefit of Macau’ and ‘diplomacy for the people’”.

item.title: Predominance of executive power
item.description: In early 2026, Xia Baolong, the director of the Hong Kong and Macao Work Office of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Office of the State Council, spoke at a seminar on the topic of “persisting and improving the predominance of executive power to boost the good governance of Special Administrative Regions”. The audience included the Chief Executives of Hong Kong and Macau, as well as members of the plenary sessions from both regions. According to the “Basic Laws” of both regions, the Chief Executive is responsible to the Central People's Government and his Special Administrative Region. In his speech, Xia Baolong highlighted that "the Chief Executive plays a crucial role and assumes significant responsibilities. He must effectively exercise the powers conferred by law, fully assume the responsibility of leading the Special Administrative Region and manage his 'house' well... striving to build an efficient and competent government." The higher the position, the greater the responsibility. The Chief Executive must assume full responsibility for the Special Administrative Region and needs to form an efficient and well-prepared Government; the responsibility is significant and the task is arduous. How to make the most of the advantages of the predominance of executive power will undoubtedly be the biggest test for the Chief Executives of both regions. The Government exists to “serve the people”, and people's degree of satisfaction and happiness is the criterion that assesses whether performance matches aspirations. If members of the Government (civil servants) cannot obtain the approval of the people, replacing them is a reasonable option. Many members of the Central Government were dismissed or detained for corruption and neglect of duty, demonstrating that no one is above the law. Since the return of Hong Kong and Macau to Chinese sovereignty, both regions have developed and progressed, but there are also limitations. Good governance is not based on empty speeches. What is clearly expressed in Xia's speech is the hope for improving and strengthening governance capacity. Let us remember the terrible fire in Tai Po, Hong Kong, which occurred at the end of last year, which is still being investigated by an independent committee. We do not know how many members of the Government will be held responsible for the incident. Furthermore, the recent measure that requires passengers to wear seat belts on public transport went through a lot of setbacks before it was implemented. For example, how can a pregnant woman be forced to wear a seat belt at the end of her term? How to deal with elderly people who prefer to stand up so they don't wear a seat belt? In Macau, with the promulgation and implementation of Law No. 5/2025 “Law on the Activity of Travel Agencies and the Tourist Guide Profession”, travel agencies are not authorized to provide shuttle bus services to inhabitants of large residential neighborhoods, which makes travel problematic, especially for domestic workers and children. With more than 40 million tourists expected to visit Macau in 2025, the capacity of public transport has been systematically tested. Although the city government has not implemented regulations against overcrowding of these vehicles, passengers continue to board buses at designated exit-only stops. The patience and tolerance of Macau residents are extraordinary, but faced with the popularity of online shopping and in mainland China, stores are emptying across the city. Even after they are renovated, when they open again, the owners are not sure how long their businesses will last. The “2026 Consumer Carnival in the North Zone” initiative demonstrates that the Macau SAR Government still needs to work to achieve good governance. Last year, when Chief Executive Sam Hou Fai invited representatives of the Portuguese and English-speaking media to the annual meal, he highly praised their professionalism, concern for social well-being and supervision of the Government's performance. At the same meeting in 2026, Chief Executive Sam Hou Fai expressed the hope that they would continue to pay attention and support the performance of the Macao SAR Government in its various aspects, reflect the living conditions of the population and offer their valid suggestions. In the context of the predominance of executive power in 2026, the media should not be limited to being an instrument of propaganda or a platform for praise, but rather play the role of advisor, supervisor and partner to help the Macao SAR Government achieve good governance.

item.title: The Little Ice Age and its social implications
item.description: Concern about the sustainability of our planet is not new. According to Professor José Pinto Peixoto1 (1922-1996), in his book “Influence of Man on Climate and Environment”2, mentioning an extract from the Book of Isaiah3, “The Earth is desolate and withered; Heaven and Earth are fading. The Earth is desecrated by its inhabitants, because they transgress the law and violate the right…”. In reality, the harmful action that the species Homo sapiens exerts on nature has intensified since around 10,000 years ago, when the agricultural revolution underwent a great increase, when man largely abandoned his activities as hunter-gatherers. With this quote, Professor JPP intended to illustrate that in ancient times there were people who were concerned about what man could do to our planet. By definition, a prophet is someone who serves as an intermediary between the divine and the people, and this text can be interpreted as a warning about the intensification of aggressions that our species would practice, and which led to the current ecological and climate crisis. Life on our planet is only possible due to a series of circumstances, including the Earth being at a distance from the Sun suitable for the existence of liquid water, a breathable atmosphere and a magnetic field that serves as a protector against electrically charged particles emitted by the Sun (solar wind), which prevents the surface from being reached by part of the radiation that is harmful to life. Since the Earth's atmosphere was formed, its characteristics have always evolved, in terms of composition and meteorological and climatic parameters. Climate change has greatly influenced human history, shaping the behavior of Homo sapiens. They have been one of the main causes of great migrations and, consequently, the emergence of different civilizations. Research in the area of ​​paleoclimatology allows us to conclude that, for millions of years, the climate was characterized by glacial and interglacial periods. During the most recent glaciation, ice invaded large areas of Europe and Asia, causing populations to migrate to lower latitudes. Around 6,000 years ago, the prolonged drought that caused the desertification of the region where the Sahara is located, caused people to flee to the Nile River valley, where a civilization flourished whose testimonies are still a source of admiration and study today. In the last million years there have been approximately six glacial periods. Although we are currently in an interglacial period, there have been shorter periods characterized by relatively low temperatures, such as what is known as the “little ice age”, between the 14th and 19th centuries. There is no unanimity about the beginning, and some historians consider that it began later, in the 16th century. There is, however, consensus that this period was characterized by harsh winters and short summers. The cause of this cooling is still debated today, which could have been a consequence of several natural factors, such as the decrease in solar activity and the increase in the concentration of particles in the atmosphere resulting from volcanic activity and the consequent reduction in radiation reaching the surface. According to some historians, the “little ice age” may have been one of the causes of social upheavals. Thus, in the United States of America, in 1692, a social phenomenon occurred that consisted of collective hysteria on the part of the population of Salem, a town in the State of Massachusetts, which resulted in a series of trials, mostly involving women accused of witchcraft. A succession of years with poor agricultural results and consequent food shortages contributed to the perception of insecurity among the populations of the New England region. Faced with this situation, the collective psychological climate contributed to hundreds of women being treated as scapegoats, some of whom were executed by hanging. This subject has been studied by several historians and served as the subject of plays, literary works and films. The most emblematic work was the play by Arthur Miller (“The Crucible” – 1953), in which the author explored this social phenomenon as a metaphor for McCarthyism, a period in US history between the late 1940s and mid-1950s, characterized by the persecution of alleged communists, inspired by Senator Joseph McCarthy. The author himself was a victim of this persecution. There were several literary works on the same subject, perhaps the most striking being the non-fiction work “The Witches: Salem, 1692” by American writer Stacy Schiff. Arthur Miller's play was adapted by Arthur Miller for the cinema in 1996, and the film was distributed in Portugal with the title “The Witches of Salem”. It was also during the Little Ice Age that great social instability occurred that preceded the start of the French Revolution. Popular dissatisfaction caused by widespread hunger due to successive natural disasters, such as a severe drought in 1788 interrupted by intense hail and hailstorms that caused the loss of a large part of the crops that had resisted. To make matters worse, the winter of 1788/1789 was extremely harsh. The melting of thick layers of snow and ice caused floods and floods the following spring, in much of France, causing serious destruction of infrastructure and almost all of the few crops that remained. Following these meteorological disasters, an outbreak of plague emerged that wiped out many of the animals that had been saved. Hunger resulted from these events and chaos ensued in large urban centers. The summer of 1789 was extremely dry, which contributed to the worsening of the situation. This entire sequence of events, together with the ineffectiveness of Louis XVI's government, contributed to social unrest, which may have constituted a kind of trigger to trigger the French revolution, one of the most notable episodes of which was the Storming of the Bastille, on July 14, 1789. It can be concluded that meteorological phenomena that, as a whole, characterize the climate of a region, contribute greatly to the worsening of social crises. For example, the recent storm that hit Portugal on January 27, 2026 (the Kristin depression, resulting from explosive cyclogenesis) generated, on the part of the affected population, a feeling of unease in relation to political power. Another example was the drought that reached its peak in 2017, which caused serious damage to agriculture, livestock, water resources and a strong environmental impact in terms of forest fires that caused dozens of fatalities. In both cases, the political power was accused, by the affected population, of not having taken the necessary measures to minimize the serious consequences that resulted from these natural disasters. Regardless of governments, natural disasters generally cause, rightly or wrongly, the feeling, on the part of the population, that their consequences could be minimized if more efficient preventive measures had been taken, such as, for example, improving forest management, strengthening infrastructure and more rigorous early weather warnings. Meteorologist References: José Pinto Peixoto – Portuguese academic. He was one of the most distinguished scientists on a global scale in the areas of Meteorology and Climatology. He was affectionately nicknamed JPP by his students and colleagues. Published in 1987 by the State Secretariat for the Environment and Natural Resources. The Prophet Isaiah, one of the writers of the Old Testament, lived between the 8th and 7th centuries BC.

item.title: The dispute over Greenland
item.description: (Continuation of the article published on January 29) The performative dimension of foreign policy plays a central role here. The possibility of taking territory from an ally, even through negotiation, would project an image of strength and unpredictability. For the White House, this unpredictability would function as a deterrent against strategic adversaries, namely Russia and China. The idea that the United States would be willing to consider bold actions in unlikely scenarios would reinforce the credibility of its threats and promises in the international system. The “capture of Maduro” is an element that would have made the use of force in unexpected contexts more plausible. Regardless of the factuality of this episode, it illustrates the internal logic of the Trump administration with high-impact actions, even if controversial, that would serve to demonstrate determination and capacity for action, creating a favorable environment to pressure partners and adversaries. In this context, Greenland would emerge as the next step in a shock strategy aimed at unlocking negotiations with Copenhagen. Although Trump's motivations have their own characteristics, there is a point of convergence between his vision and the structural interests of the American State, which is the possibility of strengthening the military presence in Greenland through the installation of a nuclear arsenal. This hypothesis is part of the logic of strategic deterrence that has guided United States defense policy since the post-war period. Greenland's geographic proximity to the Eurasian space would make the territory a privileged location for positioning weapons capable of quickly responding to threats from Russia or China. The modernization of nuclear forces, in a context of deteriorating arms control treaties, increases the likelihood that Washington will look for new places to reinforce its strategic posture. Greenland, due to its location and existing legal framework, offers particularly favorable conditions. The convergence between the symbolic ambition of the presidency and the military interests of the State thus creates a common ground that can explain the American insistence on increasing its influence on the island. Even if territorial acquisition is not necessary to achieve these objectives, the possibility of reinforcing the military presence may have contributed to legitimizing, internally, the presidential initiative. Denmark's position constitutes another essential element in understanding the dynamics surrounding Greenland. Although formally sovereign over the island, Copenhagen faces structural limitations that condition its ability to resist American pressure. Economic and military dependence on the United States, combined with the importance of NATO for European security, reduces the Danish room for maneuver. Greenland has significant internal autonomy, but remains integrated into the Kingdom of Denmark. Its population, although small, has claimed greater control over natural resources and strategic decisions that affect the territory. The American purchase proposal placed Copenhagen in a delicate position in that rejecting the offer meant contradicting a fundamental ally and accepting it would imply giving up a territory that, despite being remote, has increasing symbolic and strategic value. A recusa dinamarquesa, amplamente divulgada, não eliminou a pressão americana. On the contrary, it highlighted the fragility of the European position in the Arctic and the difficulty of reconciling national interests with the reality of an international system marked by competition between great powers. The controversy surrounding Greenland cannot be analyzed in isolation as it reflects broader transformations in the international order, including the growing militarization of the Arctic, competition for strategic resources, the redefinition of traditional alliances, the emergence of political leaders that favor symbolic gestures of great impact and the erosion of diplomatic norms that, for decades, regulated relations between allies. The proposal to purchase Greenland, although unlikely to materialize, made visible how the territory became a central piece in a global power game. The island, once peripheral, is today a space where economic, military and symbolic interests of great magnitude intersect. Thus, the analysis of American interest in Greenland reveals a complex combination of structural and cyclical factors. On the one hand, Washington seeks to ensure control of a territory essential to its military strategy and access to critical resources. On the other hand, Donald Trump's presidency introduced a symbolic and political dimension that goes beyond traditional foreign policy calculations. The attempt to acquire Greenland should not be interpreted simply as presidential eccentricity, but as an expression of a vision of power that combines historical ambition, nationalism and a strategy of calculated unpredictability. The partial convergence between this vision and the interests of the American State explains the persistence of the topic and its relevance in the international debate. Greenland, located between continents and between logics of power, has become a mirror of the tensions that shape the 21st century. The dispute over its future will continue to reflect not only the competition between States, but also the way they seek to redefine their place in a world undergoing rapid transformation.

item.title: Hotel Timor
item.description: Hotel Timor (2025) is the latest novel by Timorese writer Luís Cardoso de Noronha (b. 1958), who has lived in Portugal for many years. The consistency of Cardoso's writing, published in Portuguese publishers, is more than confirmed. What is new here is that this eighth novel of his, the announced end of a cycle dedicated to Timor, takes up much of his first book, of which it is, in a certain sense, a rewriting: Crónica de uma travessia (1997), published when its author was a representative of the Maubere resistance. We are in fact left with the feeling of closing a cycle of writing around the national issue. It is Timor, with its imagery, its people, languages, past and hopes, that remains at the forefront of his novels. Cardoso has accustomed his readers to structured writing, with many layers, dense with references. Strongly autobiographical, it has the courage to include in this novel very difficult events from the author's life, such as the murder of his brother, who disappeared in pogroms between rival political parties, formed after the Portuguese withdrew from the territory. It is then the drive to report, the so-called récit de vie, between memorialization and denunciation, which came from his first book, that internally mobilizes this Hotel Timor, a metaphor for the nation still under (re)construction, from a colonial hotel to a space in ruins until it is once again renovated as a hostel. It is precisely here that the writer and his double are seen hosting, and one of the axes of the novel is precisely this question of the double. In fact, there are several in this story. The Timorese is also someone who continually unfolds: an “original”, pre-colonial in nature, and another who was shaped by the hands of the colonizer: “The faithful and true relationship of a Timorese is with the mate-bian [the dead]. Then God, Homeland and family, in this same order, as it was at the time of the Estado Novo and the Old Empire”. (p. 23) Here the writer’s characteristic irony can be seen. The main pair of doubles is, however, made up of the first protagonist, who shares many characteristics with the empirical author, but is not him. There are two parallel returns to today's Timor: that of a famous writer who comes to be decorated and another of a modest cruise singer who comes looking for a lost lover. It is the latter who begins speaking in the first person in the novel, and we are told that he is the one who has written the author's novels; this one, which does not exist, or which exists less than the other. In other words, the real is divided between what came into being and what remained potential, and it is through what is in the shadow that writing and other real things come, which implies a particular aesthetic conception. It also involves a game of concealment: one thing is said to hide another; one thing is hidden to bring another to light. Whoever speaks in this novel is, then, pure potentiality, a ghost. It's a life possibility for the empirical writer that never materialized, as far as we know: romantic singer on cruises. Reality (written or not) would be a kind of chiasmus between these two planes. If it is, then, the writer's double who actually writes the novels of the author who accepts being awarded a medal, it is because he is the writer and, simultaneously, an envoy of the ancestors. The author is just a big shot to whom medals can be thrown and hands shaken at ceremonies. The dead and ghosts both belong to the same latent world. Another way of saying that there is no point in giving a medal to the writer, because the person who writes his novels is (his) shadow, the unconscious, the drift — which is another way of putting things for those for whom such things don't make sense. Now, the world of spirits, of shadows, in short, the remote world of Timorese animist traditions, very present in countless references in Tetum and in the structuring logic of the book itself, is not a picturesque folklore that surrounds it, but a present, active thing. It did not fade during Cardoso's long exile: it informs his books, where the dead come to speak, as Raul Brandão said about his. The dead shape their literature from the other side, and it serves as communication with them. The world of spirits and the world of the living are like two communicating arms of an hourglass, connected by the sand of the voice. This is, I think, the richest and most dynamic aspect of the book. Another, of no less importance, is the fact that the pages of the novel operate an inflation of memory in a country robbed of its past and memory, not only because it is a recent nation, but also because of the heavy damage caused by colonialism and the invasion by its neighbor. In a land where libraries are scarce, the book aims to build a kind of minimal library of Timor through citations and references, which reproduces the orature of its people. It aims to create memory, a very necessary process. It is, therefore, natural that it is also an accumulation and a review of the novel library composed by the author, abundant in references to all his previous work, and which feed the novelistic game, as when referring to the Pensão Buganvília, “the same one where Catarina, the fundamental character of the book Requiem for a solitary navigator (…) stayed (…). Having not found any inn with that name, he made a reservation at the Hotel Timor” (p. 19). The library also serves to reveal the sources from which Hotel Timor draws and make its readings an explicit aspect of writing. It is a book constructed based on short speeches, bits of dialogue that serve as a motto for countless digressions, as the narrative itself is meager, just a sketch: doubles return to Timor at the same time and with the same passport, staying in the same hotel. Um deles é um cantor romântico que finalmente volta para tentar encontrar a sua amada; o outro é o escritor famoso. Esta história quase burlesca permite um mínimo de personagens e de cenas que espoletam recordações, falas internas e externas. O diálogo é, assim, modo de lançar um mote para uma deriva informe, ao modo loboantuniano, que enche todo o romance. It thus seems that there are several narrators, also in the style of the author of As Naus: the writer's double, his brother who was shot, perhaps others, who segregate memories, episodes and fragments relating to their lives, but always in terms of Timor. It is Timor who is behind it all and who connects all the scattered voices, and this is how one realizes that what is constant in this book, without ever affecting the depth of its intertwining of various traditions (Timorese, Portuguese, Lusophone, European) and countless references from literature and music (Kadaré, Piaf, Dylan Thomas, Mia Couto), is the ironic but good-humored criticism of the destinies of a post-colonial Timor ravaged by nepotism. The writing is not only a criticism of customs, but a small great revenge: for the prizes he almost received, for the other lives he and his family could have lived if the history of his country had not been the ordeal it was. Despite everything, a Timorese can write in Portuguese and win awards for it (this is what happened to the author, who received the Oceanos in 2021), especially considering that Portuguese is not his mother tongue, it is his work. It is, in a way, a deserved revenge for Manufahi, perhaps the only one possible, as it is a battle won on the “spiritual” terrain of the colonizer, his language. We know that the writer is a direct descendant of Liurals who participated in that last bloody uprising against Portugal, and who lost out, which took place in 1912 in the province of Manufahi. But his grandson's spear stuck deep in the shield that the Portuguese have used to defend themselves around the world: the language. Thus, for this command of language and narrative mastery, Cardoso has already deserved recognition. And let us not be surprised that those who have already published in large publishing groups are now in independent publishers, which are sometimes more welcoming. His Pumpkin Planter had appeared in Abysmo, by João Paulo Cotrim, and is now published by a publisher with an English-speaking name, but which publishes mainly in Portuguese, Poets and Dragons Society. It is good to have a writer of this magnitude in independent publishers, but the book, full of typos (even in Timorese names), deserved to have a review, which clearly did not happen, and is now in its second edition.

item.title: Chinese New Year | Votive papers session at Fundação Rui Cunha
item.description: The Rui Cunha Foundation (FRC) today hosts the second session of the “Fai Chun – Votive Paper Offering” initiative, in celebration of the Chinese New Year. Therefore, those interested and curious can stop by the gallery to receive the votive papers, which are messages of good luck in Chinese calligraphy, between 10am and 4pm. The papers are free, being an event co-organized by the Poetry Association of Friends of Jardim da Flora. The FRC welcomes 41 calligraphy masters and poets who will create happy phrases and verse couplets alluding to the celebrations of the New Lunar Year of the Horse. Fai Chun is a traditional decoration used during Chinese New Year, which marks the arrival of the spring season. In Portuguese it can be translated as Onda de Primavera. People place Fai Chun on doors to create a happy and festive atmosphere, as the calligraphed phrases mean good luck and prosperity. Normally, traditional Fai Chun are red in color, with black or gold characters inscribed with a brush, which aim to protect the houses with good wishes for the year ahead. Nowadays, printed versions are more common and produced on a large scale. They can be square or rectangular and hung vertically or horizontally, usually in pairs. They not only exist in China, but also in Korea, Japan and Vietnam. 2026 is the Year of the Fire Horse, which begins on February 17, 2026 (the first day of the Chinese New Year) and lasts until February 5, 2027. The Horse is the seventh of the 12 signs of the Chinese zodiac.

item.title: Boi Warehouse | Three artists present new visions of Macau
item.description: Armazém do Boi reveals, from the 13th of February, the works of three Chinese artists who carried out artistic residencies in the territory and who, with their art, outlined new visions of the territory they temporarily inhabited. “O Viajante da Montagem”, “Waste: Soup without Water” and “With Who I Am” are the results of this type of fieldwork Armazém do Boi has long accustomed us to bringing new visions of the territory with the work of local artists, but also from abroad. The new triptych of exhibitions, to be opened on the 13th of February, will once again reveal to the public new readings about this common and shared space that is Macau. One of the exhibitions is by artist Liao Yu-An, entitled “The Drifter of Assemblage – Red and Blue, Color Fields and Monsters”. This is the result of a month of experiences in Macau, where the artist “gained awareness of the fragmented and complex nature of the city”. In Armazém do Boi's note about this exhibition, it is described that Liao Yu-An sees Macau as “a place where scales oscillate between the miniature and the monumental”, and where “multiple facets coexist in dense proximity, resembling a richly layered and intensely flavorful stew”. In this presentation, “the artist absorbs and reflects on these sensory impressions, translating them into different pictorial expressions”. More specifically, what the public will be able to see are three sets of works that examine “the mechanisms of transformation between visual signs, urban color structures and a subjective perceptual experience”. Here, painting is nothing more than “a practice of perceptual translation and experiential reconstruction”. "Between montage and transformation, painting stops being just a means of representing reality, becoming a continuous action that generates perception. Colors, images and fragmented experiences intertwine to form a fluid trajectory of visualization, guiding the public on a sensorial journey situated between the city, the body and the imagination", the same note describes. Another work that will be presented from the 13th is “Residues: Soup without Water” [Dregs: Soup without Water], by Biyi Zhu, curated and academic work by Vivien Chan. In this exhibition, there are meanings that are taken from a kind of imaginary dictionary, in which waste is seen as “the last drop, grain or molecule spread at the bottom of the pan”. “Residues: Soup without Water” refers to what remains “after all the soup has been eaten”, looking at the “soft and moist consistency” of the waterless remains of a soup traditionally prepared according to the rules of Cantonese cuisine. Thus, Biyi Zhu asks: “What are the possibilities of what remains?”, clinging, through art, to “the remains of the past”. This is a return to Macau after a ten-year stay in the Netherlands, and in this exhibition, “Zhu uses the processes and materialities of Cantonese soup to explore ways of traveling in time, between places, relationships and lives”. "After drinking the soup, the residue becomes proof of what was absorbed by the body, by the atmosphere. Taking what would normally be discarded, Zhu transforms the residue into tangible forms, dissolving and reformulating ideas of memory, kinship, migration and waste", it further reads. Personal issues The third exhibition space is composed of “Who Am I With”, by Li Aixiao, curated by Wendy Wong. This is an exhibition with a more personal nature, which begins with the artist’s “self”, when he “enters the lives, languages ​​and objects of others”. To do this, he uses performance, photography and other artistic interactions “to persistently question with whom and how we establish connections in this place”. "The works unfold between the approaching and distancing of the body and between the occurrence and interruption of exchange, where some connections take root while others remain in the realm of the unfulfilled. As viewers navigate and observe, they perceive the transitory transformation of identity and the emergence or absence of intimacy, witnessing how language, images and objects serve as modes of presence", it is described. In this way, “these works point to a state of coexistence that remains perpetually unstable, but that occasionally awakens rare and authentic connections at the moment of encounter”. The three exhibitions can be seen free of charge until March 15th.

item.title: Cultural heritage of Chongqing and Xinjiang on display
item.description: The Cultural Institute (IC), together with a series of entities from China, is preparing to present an exhibition in Macau that will reveal some of the intangible cultural heritage of the Chinese regions of Chongqing and Xinjiang, namely traditional tapestry. The exhibition, presented at the Tap Seac Gallery from next Wednesday, 11th, is entitled “Splendid Colors: Embroidery Art Exhibition from Chongqing and the Uyghur Autonomous Region of Xinjiang”, which opens at 6:30 pm. According to a note from the IC, this exhibition presents a “careful selection” of 154 works or sets of artistic embroidery from the cities of Chongqing and the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, including Shu embroidery, Wuxi marriage embroidery, Youzhou Miao embroidery and “Xilankapu” brocade (traditional Tujia weaving), as well as the three embroidery techniques of the Uyghur and Kyrgyz ethnic groups. and Kazakh from Xinjiang. “All of these techniques were inscribed as representative items of intangible cultural heritage at national or municipal level, and all works are created by transmitters of intangible cultural heritage and masters of crafts and art, showing the elegance of Southern embroidery and the vibrant and bold colors of Northern embroidery.” The IC adds, in the same note, that these embroidery works “not only reveal a remarkable technique and a varied style, but also contain the cultural depth of the ethnicities involved”. Materials, motifs and color schemes are presented that “incorporate the aesthetic sensitivity and creativity transmitted from generation to generation, expressing the aspirations and desire of the people for a better life”. Art of good embroidery The opening day, as well as the 12th of February, promises surprises for participants and interested parties, since at 10 am, 11:30 am, 3 pm and 5 pm, several intangible cultural heritage transmitters will be present who will demonstrate embroidery techniques, lasting approximately one hour per session. Furthermore, in March, namely on the 7th and 8th, thematic workshops take place with the same transmitters of this heritage. One of them is the workshop on the Chongqing Shu embroidery technique, scheduled for March 7th; The next day the workshop on Xinjiang embroidery technique takes place. The two initiatives take place in the Activities Room of the Xian Xinghai Memorial Museum, located on Rua de Francisco Xavier Pereira. Participation in the workshops is free and sessions will be conducted in Mandarin, with a maximum of 16 participants per session. Residents aged 16 or over will be able to register from 10am on February 12th, through the “Activities Registration” section of the Macau Single Account. The IC describes the art of embroidery as being “one of the most representative traditional crafts of the Chinese ethnic group, containing a deep historical heritage and rich artistic creativity, with multiple practical, aesthetic, etiquette and cultural transmission values”. This exhibition can be visited until March 15th.

item.title: MAM | Macau hosts Vieira da Silva exhibition at the end of the year
item.description: The Arpad Szenes Museum – Vieira da Silva, dedicated to the work of Portuguese painter Maria Helena Vieira da Silva and artist Arpad Szenes, is preparing to present in the Macao SAR an exhibition that presents a retrospective of the work of one of the most influential contemporary Portuguese artists, who died in 1992 The Macau Art Museum (MAM) joined forces with the Arpad Szenes-Vieira da Silva Foundation museum, based in Lisbon, to present a retrospective exhibition of the work of Portuguese painter Maria Helena Vieira da Silva, considered one of the great names in contemporary Portuguese art. This exhibition is part of the activity plan for this year at the Arpad Szenes-Vieira da Silva Museum and was revealed to Lusa by Nuno Faria, its director, when asked about the internationalization plan for the museum space. The exhibition in Macau will consist of works from the institution's collection, forming part of “a context of growing international interest in the artist”. “We were challenged by our partners to hold a large exhibition in Macau with works from our collection and other collections, and we are working on this exhibition, which will take place at the end of the year and will coincide with the Arpad Szenes anthology in Lisbon”, said the person in charge. According to Nuno Faria, the recent exhibitions of Maria Helena Vieira da Silva's work “raised a very visible interest in the retrospective exhibition at the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, which shed new light” on the Portuguese artist's work. “This will be Vieira [da Silva]'s first major exhibition in China”, said the director of the museum opened in 1994 in the former Fábrica das Sedas, in Amoreiras, Lisbon, following the creation of the Arpad Szenes-Vieira da Silva Foundation, in 1990, intended to house and publicize the estate of the two painters. Still with regard to internationalization, it is planned to present at the Embassy of Portugal, in The Hague, in the Netherlands, an exhibition dedicated to the graphic work of Vieira da Silva, bringing together a significant nucleus of the foundation's collection. Doubles and coincidences Furthermore, the year 2026 holds exhibitions dedicated to Rui Sanches, João Paulo Feliciano and Lourdes Castro for the Arpad Szenes-Vieira da Silva Museum, with the annual exhibition plan being organized into three cycles. In Lisbon, the museum will host exhibitions, among other artists, by Teresa Segurado Pavão, Frida Baranek, Vasco Futscher, Carlos Noronha Feio, Mariana Caló and Francisco Queimadela.
