Nuno Faria said that the exhibition program will continue to value the work of the founding artists and promote dialogue with contemporary creation, alongside investing in the international circulation of the institution's “rich, broad and diverse” collection. The first exhibition cycle opens on February 10th and includes the exhibition “Arpad Szenes and Vieira da Silva: nuclei of the collection”, bringing together fundamental works by the two artists, “organized in a diachronic and thematic reading that highlights the evolution and main lines of their productions”. In the same period, “Essays in Immobility and Secret Movement” will be presented, which brings together sculptures by Rui Sanches and Teresa Segurado Pavão, in an unprecedented collaboration between the two artists. “There are two artists who have this happy coincidence – like Vieira da Silva and Arpad Szenes – of being a couple, Rui Sanches dedicated to sculpture and drawing, and Teresa Pavão to ceramics and textiles”, pointed out Nuno Faria, highlighting that, according to the invited authors, “this unprecedented partnership between four hands will be unrepeatable”. The museum's second exhibition cycle runs from the 21st of May to the 13th of September and includes a new presentation of the cores of the Arpad Szenes and Vieira da Silva collection, deepening the reading of the work, and an exhibition dedicated to Lourdes Castro (1930-2022), with unpublished initial drawings, works and documentation from the 1950s and 1960s, developed in partnership with MUDAS — Museu de Arte Contemporânea da Wood. The third cycle will be dedicated almost entirely to an anthological exhibition of the work of Arpad Szenes (1897-1985), based on in-depth research into his pictorial and graphic production, with the aim of presenting new readings of the artist's work and promoting the international circulation of the project. “This is perhaps the most challenging exhibition we are going to do this year”, said the museum director to Lusa, adding that the entire museum space will be dedicated to Arpad Szenes.

item.title: Game | Fewer illegal loans in 2025
item.description: Last year, the Judiciary Police initiated a total of 192 investigations related to illegal gambling loans, which represented a drop of 23.8 percent compared to 2024. The numbers were released yesterday during a symposium on last year's statistics. Despite there being fewer loans, the number of gambling-related investigations opened increased by 62.6 percent, to a total of 2,314. This increase was justified with the crime of illegally exchanging money for gambling. This was a practice that local authorities always understood was not necessary to criminalize. However, in 2024, after criticism from the Interior in which the practice of these money exchanges in Macau was identified as a vulnerability for the country's security, the Macao SAR Government ended up moving forward with criminalization. In the statements made, Sit Chong Meng, director of the PJ, stated that since the law combating illegal exchanges of money for gambling came into force until December 2025, 567 cases were concluded, which led to the arrest of 867 people. Police seized more than 94 million Hong Kong dollars, with some operations conducted in cooperation with Homeland authorities. According to the newspaper Ou Mun, the increase in crime also resulted from “statistical improvements”, which were not specified. Sit also warned that “as law enforcement initiatives intensify, the activities of money exchange gangs have become increasingly secretive and criminal patterns more sophisticated.” However, the person responsible promised that the PJ “will closely and persistently monitor” the criminal networks that use legitimate businesses to hide these illegal exchanges.

item.title: Emperor | Sold gold from the ground for 100 million
item.description: The Emperor group, responsible for the hotel with the same name in Macau, agreed to sell several gold bars that were placed on the hotel floor. The announcement was made yesterday to the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, and the sale of the metal was agreed for 99.7 million Hong Kong dollars, which should represent a net profit of 90.2 million. Regarding the reasons for selling the gold, the group explains that it is part of a new strategy for operating the hotel, given the end of the operation of the gaming space, which in the past made the Emperor Hotel a satellite casino. “Following the closure of its gaming operations, the Group has been actively planning other entertainment and amusement facilities to enhance its overall hospitality experience and broaden its revenue base,” it was noted. “The precious metals that were originally part of the hotel’s interior design and equipment are no longer relevant to the hotel’s theme in the future,” it was added. The company's Board of Directors also explained that the sale is taking place at a time when the value of gold has reached historic figures. The buyer is the company Heraeus Metals Hong Kong, representing the German group Heraeus, founded in 1660, which is dedicated to activities such as trading precious metals, recycling, healthcare, electronic products and semiconductors.

item.title: MGM China | Profits rose 10.7 percent
item.description: The lion dealership announced annual revenue growth that promises an auspicious entry into the Year of the Horse. In 2025, MGM China announced record profits of $1.2 billion Macau gaming operator MGM China announced record profits of US$1.2 billion in 2025, an annual increase of 10.7 percent. This is the third consecutive year with a new maximum, after, in 2023, MGM China registered a historic record of earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization (EBITDA) of around 921 million dollars and, in 2024, approximately 1.13 million dollars. These data, according to a statement sent to the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday, were published “inadvertently”, as the publication date was scheduled for February 11th. The results, the company wrote, will be released today “after the market closes” Also according to the document, in the last quarter of last year, MGM China achieved profits of US$332.3 million, an increase of 30.5 percent compared to the same period last year (US$254.7 million). The company ended the year with an annual increase of 10.9 percent in revenue, with earnings of US$4.5 billion in 2025 compared to US$4.02 billion obtained in the previous year. In quarterly terms, MGM China achieved net revenues of US$1.24 billion in the last three months of the year, which represents an increase of 21.4 percent compared to the same period in 2024 (US$1.02 billion). Above expected In reaction to the announced results, cited by the GGR Asia portal, the financial services company Jefferies considered that they were between 3 percent and 5 percent above expectations. However, yesterday was marked by a suspension of trading in MGM China shares on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. The suspension took place in the morning, after the parent company, MGM Resorts, had “inadvertently” announced the results of MGM China, even before it was communicated to the Hong Kong Bola authorities. Six gaming concessionaires, MGM, Galaxy, Venetian, Melco, Wynn and SJM, operate in Macau, the only place in China where casino gambling is legal. Casinos in the region closed 2024 with revenue of 226.8 billion patacas, 23.9 percent more than in 2023 (183.1 billion patacas). Macau casino revenues reached 247.4 billion patacas last year, an increase of 9.1 percent compared to the previous year.

item.title: Hengqin New District | Less than 40% of homes sold
item.description: Until last January, 1,610 apartments had been sold to residents in the New Neighborhood of Macau in Hengqin, according to data revealed to HM. Between the end of 2024 and last month, 222 units were sold, less than the apartments sold in Macau in November alone The sale of apartments in the New District of Macau in Hengqin continues to follow a pace well below the local market, even with the crisis that the real estate sector is going through. According to data revealed by Macau Urban Renewal to HM, by January 2026, 1,610 apartments had been sold in the New Neighborhood of Macau to Macao SAR residents, which represents a proportion of 39.5 percent of the total available units. At the end of May last year, Macau Urban Renovation's annual report revealed that 1,388 apartments had been purchased in the Ilha da Montanha housing complex since they went on sale in November 2023, which represented only 34 percent of the total volume of units (4,070). All in all, between the end of 2024 and last month, 222 units were sold in the New Macau District in Hengqin, a volume lower than the sales recorded in Macau only last November, when data from the Financial Services Department revealed 238 units sold, despite the crisis affecting the real estate sector in the Macao SAR. House of talents The anemic sales record in the housing complex for Macau residents in the Hengqin Deep Cooperation Zone takes on a more serious tone given the lifting of restrictions that the Hengqin authorities have introduced since 2024. This week, it was announced that Macau residents can purchase two units in the housing complex. However, Hengqin authorities implemented successive measures to boost sales. The criteria have been adjusted, including the removal of the age limit, allowing minors to own property, the restriction on resale within five years of purchase has been removed, as well as the adjustment of the limit on purchasing residential units. Furthermore, in September 2025, Macau Urban Renewal announced the start of sales of units in Tower 11 of the housing complex, with prices at special discounts for parking spaces, renovation works and the purchase of household appliances. The public capital company also indicated to HM that 200 apartments were reserved and leased to “entities that meet the criteria” to house non-resident talent. The lease of these fractions in the New Neighborhood of Macau was established in the land use right transfer contract signed on April 21, 2020 for the project. The accommodation for these qualified staff was reserved in towers 17 and 18 of the housing complex.

item.title: Airport | CAM aims for 8.14 million passengers in 2026
item.description: After a year of 2025 in which the airport lost passengers and commercial flights, those responsible for CAM – Sociedade do Aeroporto Internacional de Macau believe that 2026 will be different. According to figures presented during a Lunar New Year lunch, organized yesterday, the company estimates it will receive 8.14 million passengers and 63,000 commercial flight arrivals and departures throughout this year. The numbers indicated by the company, and cited by the newspaper Ou Mun, represent an annual increase of 8.2 percent in the number of passengers and 8.6 percent in the number of arrivals and departures of commercial flights. The annual estimate for the number of passengers in 2026 is still below what happened before the pandemic. In 2019, the airport received a total of 9.61 million passengers, the highest figure since it began operating, and in the previous year it had received 8.26 million passengers. The increase in the number of passengers is expected, despite the chairman of the company's Executive Committee, Simon Chan Weng Hong, having revealed that from October this year until October 2029 the airport will be closed between night and 8am. The closure was justified by the expansion of infrastructure and landfill. Regarding these works, Simon Chan stated that a “minimal impact” on the operation of the airport is expected. The president of the CAM Executive Committee also revealed that new restaurants will open at the airport in April, offering meals prepared by some of the best-known local brands.

item.title: Nipah Virus | Government prepares aviation sector response capacity
item.description: On Tuesday, the Health Services held a lecture “Knowledge about Nipah virus infection”, aimed at representatives of the Civil Aviation Authority, CAM, Sociedade do Aeroporto Internacional de Macau, S.A.R.L. and airlines. The Health Services (SS) indicated yesterday that the event aimed to inform and raise awareness of the cases of Nipah virus infection detected in the state of West Bengal, in eastern India, as well as improving the response capacity of the aviation sector. More than 100 managers and frontline workers listened to explanations about transmission routes, clinical symptoms and important points of personal protection. Authorities highlighted the importance of the border post as “the first line of defense against the importation of serious infectious diseases”, by airport professionals and airlines to protect the health of residents. The SS also guaranteed the reinforcement of the assessment and medical examination of individuals with relevant travel history who present symptoms at border posts. To this end, an “effective interdepartmental coordination mechanism was created with the airport, the Civil Aviation Authority and the competent services”. Furthermore, “according to the global national investigation and the risk assessment of the World Health Organization”, currently, the impact of the Nipah virus for Macau is “relatively low”.

item.title: Uber | Deputy calls for regulation and questions data processing
item.description: Leong Sun Iok is concerned about the lack of regulation of online taxi services, in response to Uber's re-entry in Macau, and advocates the creation of a specific law to protect the rights of passengers and drivers. The deputy also questions the location of Uber's servers The use of mobile applications to hail taxis has been a consensus throughout the world for many years, with the exception of Macau. Uber's restart of operations in Macau, announced on Tuesday, immediately prompted reactions to return to the old order, or concerns about opening services. One of the voices of consternation is MP Leong Sun Iok. The Operários legislator is concerned about the lack of regulation of applications to request taxi services, and of a specific law that guarantees the rights of passengers and drivers. As such, he expects the Government to come forward with legislation soon. Speaking to the newspaper Ou Mun, the deputy argued that if a passenger cancels a reservation, the taxi driver will not have the strength to compensate for the loss. The same can happen to the customer if the platform has temporary problems that lead to the cancellation of the order. Although Uber has guaranteed that the fares charged are the same, “according to the official meter”, Leong Sun Iok stated that current legislation prohibits the charging of additional fares, but that there are platforms that charge them anyway. Looking for trouble The transport service between Macau and Hong Kong provided by Uber also worries the deputy, who highlighted that the law requires the vehicle to be licensed and the driver to have a taxi driver identification card to avoid infractions. Remember that in this aspect, Uber indicated that the service will be run by a cross-border transport operator, the company Kwoon Chung Bus Holdings. In the deputy's view, although Uber exclusively uses taxis licensed from Macau, the customer must be alert and confirm the legality of the vehicle, because in the event of a road accident it may not be covered by insurance. In this regard, Leong Sun Iok also called on the Government to combat illegal taxis. The “uncertain” location of Uber’s data servers represents another fear of Leong Sun Iok, as Macao SAR legislation requires the installation of servers in Macau, a requirement that four online taxi platforms comply with.

item.title: ZELENSKY VS ZELENSKY
item.description:
10/27/22 A Ukrainian pensioner, with the same name as the president, blames Zelensky for the prolongation of the conflict that destroyed his village. Zelensky, the villager, who never left his land, is now mortified because his favorite gravedigger died in the bomber. This Zelensky, a villager, represents half the world that recriminates the other Zelensky, the villain, for not wanting to negotiate with Putin. Negotiate what? The invader enters our house, covers his wife and daughter (cf. recent UN report on the rapes in Ukraine, in this “special operation”), an act that forced us to watch, and then we say to him: hi there, we are for peace, but we have to negotiate: you still haven't said what name you want to give the children! A peace that is not dignified is nothing more than a cessation of rights. As serious as the Russophobia that Putin inflicts on his people.
10/28/22 At a lunch with several guests, I heard a friend, who declared herself a spiritualist, explaining the particularities of her belief, in a calm and balanced way, I would even say, without a hint of “irrationalism”. He spoke at length and serenely, devoid of any fanatical proselytism. “Here is someone whose belief has brought thoughtfulness!” I thought, a rare alliance. However, at a certain moment a sentence comes out that horrifies me. It says, “there is no chance, nothing happens by chance!”, and I glimpse the voracious maws of holism. Because holism has a pathological aspect, like all good things, a shadow side. Two examples: in Hinduism there is less sensitivity to existential dramas, if that child suffers in this life this is just an expression of rigorous karmic symmetry, an effect of the acts he committed in his previous life. In Africa, it is not accepted that death could have been accidental, and many women are accused by the family of the deceased of having caused the death of their husband, in an act of manifest dementia, and, in the blatant majority of cases, a huge injustice for the wife — madness that spreads and infiltrates the social fabric. Buddhism introduced Compassion and Christianity introduced Caritas, trying to break with this logic, but in many other beliefs and religions the cage of causalities prevails over sensitivity to experience, the need to respond to the now. It is a tremendous logic that transforms the world into a Platonic stage, where we are nothing more than the shadows of something — an inextricable law -, in a determinism that calcifies all singularities, but that strangely fascinates many. The conquest of modernity was anchored in the conquest of chance and randomness, removing the incidences of a life from this fierce determinism that enclosed the world in a web. When the Renaissance freed the body from the influence of the stars, at that moment sexuality was relieved of guilt and individualism and its volition were able to emerge. There is an unequivocal moral implication in the phrase “there is no such thing as chance, nothing happens by chance!”, which should function as a key to self-knowledge and self-judgment, however, this phrase is usually used to seek a reason for things outside of us, in others. It's an alibi. Today there is a holistic temptation in the world, just as there was a satanic temptation in the Middle Ages, without much reflection on its consequences. Because it's not enough to want to connect everything in a resonant chain of affection. Even for the most unexpected: affection itself can kill. I realize, thanks to that cultured, balanced, intelligent woman, that “the fight” took place at the beginning of this century. One of the great mistakes of the 20th century was the false dichotomy between “rationalism and irrationalism”, a debate that extended to all fields, including art. First, rationality (the positive side of reason) was confused with rationalism (the pathological aspect of reason), and articulated in this lack of discernment, irrationalism was confused with freedom. Almost all 20th century art, with Surrealism at its head, made this mistake. The fallacy still exists despite the emergence of “irrationalism” and the consequent relativist currents that followed it having been consolidated everywhere. Essentially, much of what happened in the 20th century revolved around this clash between two paradigms: Rationalism versus Irationalism. Now, I see, we must save indeterminacy, chance, randomness from the terrible temptation of the cage of causalities. Holism, in its pathological form, may be reductionism that sets itself up as a new “eschatological narrative”. Is it “by chance” that holism emerges at a time when neo-liberalism and its cynical contempt for the human person is besieging everything, all freedoms, all acquired rights? Holistic awareness has brought a positive impact to greater ecological awareness, but followed with scholastic rigor, it stifles reality under the blanket of a determinism that is much more than uncomfortable: all great authoritarian ideologies are holistic. My friend will know how to combine her holistic and transpersonal belief with the freedom and responsibility that each moment asks of us — but how many will make the distinction, under a Law that explains and encompasses everything? How many will abandon themselves to what is? The awareness of the indeterminate brings tragic awareness, as the Greeks knew, but it also brings agency and the courage of decision. And we cannot give up on this. Furthermore, as Drummond shows in the poem “Quadrilha”, by Carlos Drummond de Andrade: «João loved Teresa who loved Raimundo/ who loved Maria who loved Joaquim who loved Lili/ who didn't love anyone./ João went to the United States, Teresa to the convent,/ Raimundo died of a disaster, Maria stayed with her aunt,/ Joaquim committed suicide and Lili married J. Pinto Fernandes/ who had not entered the story.» Real always runs outside the track, completely outside our concepts. That's what matters to us — a J. Pinto Fernandes emerges at the exact moment when we thought we had everything under control.

item.title: From Nobel and others
item.description: 9/10/22 When reading many people's reactions when this year's Nobel Prize for Literature was announced, I couldn't help but remember this comment from Jean-Pierre Siméon, in relation to another Nobel Prize: «An editor of a large national daily newspaper wrote five lines of indignation at the fact that the Nobel Prize for Literature had been awarded to Thomas Traströmer, a complete stranger. But unknown to whom? How did it not occur to this literary columnist, patented and paid to do his job, that his apparent ignorance was a matter of professional misconduct? Tranströmer had been translated into many languages, it was available in French.» There is always the chorus of those who wait for the Prize to be announced to complain about not having been invited to be on the jury, there is a subgroup of angry people who profess “I have never read it and I won’t even bother to read it”; It is a less than humble fauna, the one that inhabits social networks. I don't always know all the winners – I didn't know about the existence of Louise Glück, who I think is a great poet, or Olga Tokarczuk, for example – but this only brings me the comfort of knowing that the world is not a soap opera where everyone knows everyone else and the joy of recognizing that the yardstick of the world is not measured with my short measure and that, on the contrary, it gives me a new opportunity to face the unknown and learn from it. And perhaps the most stupid reaction was that of the intelligent man who wrote, But are there still people who read French?; simply confirming that today there is a new type of ignorance that is being raised with abandon: that of those who only read English. I would also prefer that, in French, Pascal Quignard, Linda Lê or even Sollers were awarded, or, among the new ones, Mathias Énard, but that does not detract from the dignity of Annie Ernaux's work (and it would have been enough to have written “Les Années”). There are books of hers that I like less, like the vulgar “Uma Paixão Simples”, but that happens with almost all authors, they have pivotal books and others that are like breaks in their itinerary. I recommend reading a beautiful book of interviews with her, “L’écriture comme un couteau”. 11/10/22 Yesterday an article appeared in the morning newspaper “Notícias”, in Maputo, reporting that the Pen Club Narrative Prize had been awarded to my wife, Teresa Noronha, for her soap opera “Tornado”, which had already won the Maria Velho da Costa Prize. The summary they made of the book does not even deserve comments, as it is pathetic, but what is important to highlight is the note of disqualification regarding its “Mozambicanness” when they call it Luso-Mozambican. It's not that it's inaccurate, but, for those who know the context, it's a touch naughty. Because finally, following the same logic, Adelino Timóteo should be called Tsonga-Mozambican, Álvaro Taruma Ronga-Mozambican, and Macua-Mozambican for writers from the north, etc., etc. Which doesn't appear to happen. At one point, in the novel, she writes: «Our color was never the dominant one. In colonial times we were not white, we were dressed in monhés, mugs of washed asses, the pejorative term to speak of a son of Goan and Portuguese. In the post-colonial period, I was not black and if, in Lisbon, they took me for Brazilian or Cape Verdean, in France they were lost in thought about where I was from and were surprised when they discovered that I was African. There I had to explain the wanderings of my DNA before settling in Mozambique. It took me a long time to accept that it was like that because yes, and that it was no curse that that was the case; on the contrary, I could even discover intense patterns of fantasy and freedom in this harlequin cloak that is our genealogy…” In modern-day Mozambique, it means being white… and that immediately takes precedence over what you do or what you are. It's sad, but as Naipaul warned, in these parts race is everything and people live as deeply immersed in it as, in other places, in religion. 12/10/22 Bruno Latour, an anthropologist who studied the sciences and their procedures and legitimations, law, technique and religions and who entertained himself by turning his back on the dogmas of the “moderns”, has died. For him, the place, the role of the specialist, was defined more by the perplexity he embodied than by the supposed truth that would sustain him. He proposed, as an alternative to the goodness of multiculturalism and its equivocal cliché “all different, all equal”, a return to “diplomacy”, given that this, precisely, does not start from the assumption that “we are unified because we share the same nature” but simply highlights that we “still do not share a common world”; It is necessary that we deal head-on with the “abyss of disagreement” that separates us, instead of trying to deceive it. And about politics he said, boldly: «If transparency is demanded from politicians, we kill them; if anyone demands fidelity to what the other was or what he says, kill him; If a mimetic relationship is required between what the crowd wants and what its representative says, representation is killed. These must therefore, by definition, betray, deceive, modify, distort the word. Without this ability to bend the word and betray, political language would not exist. I put forward the perfectly plausible hypothesis that political vocabulary will become as inaccessible as the religious language of the last twenty, three or fifty years.» (in “Un Monde Pluriel mais Commun”). I believe we will be needed to decipher this frantically complex world that has fallen to us.

item.title: Fuxi
item.description: O my friends, companions of these disastrous journeys through countries as old as the stars and the Moon, and as strange as the deepest interior of our wretched souls, what surprises still await us, what secret magics will we still have to overcome, what horrors will arise before our pupils dilated with astonishment and terror? Increasingly closer to our precarious existences, howls the monster of war, which threatens to merge humanity once and for all with the earth, incessantly traversed by the squalid specter of hunger and the invisible evil of ten thousand pestilences. Oh damned human, who believes you are superior to Nature itself, but then you reveal yourself, time and time again, incapable of simply ordering your existence and do not understand that you are possessed by fickle anger and are a slave to your own ambition! You are not satisfied with white jade or resplendent gold, there is no treasure that quenches your inextinguishable thirst for command over other men, animals and things; for eternal anguish dwells in you; in you the expelled serpents crawl; for you grows, powerful and impressive, the most fertile ivy of Evil! This is perhaps why on the Mount they call the White Deer, where one of the eight immortals on a sacred mount soared through the heavens towards Penglai, lives the fuxi, a bird whose shape resembles that of a rooster, although topped by a human head. What strange copulations, what monstrous embraces, what terrible procedures must have occurred to make the existence of this sinister animal possible? We don't know, but all it takes is for our exhausted mind to dare to come up with an answer, and then we feel our skin covered in horrendous goosebumps and our heart races in parade, like a wild horse whipped by the night whip of fear, unresponsive to reins and containment. Let men refrain from visiting Monte do Veado, because despite the fact that there are riches capable of calming the wildest ambitions, if they have the unfortunate luck of catching a glimpse of a fuxi, it is certain that a war will soon break out and the cultivated fields will perish, because of it the tame animals will be beheaded, because of it the best young men of two generations will be sacrificed and the pride of the countries will be destroyed. The fuxi makes a sound reminiscent of its name. If you hear it, dark night or clear day, be on your way, because the path you are on is the surest path to misfortune!

item.title: Procrastinators Club
item.description: While rereading Easter, because of an article I'm preparing, I come across this excerpt, taken from “The Universal Man”: «Each man, morally, is one and absolute; but he has to live with attenuating his personality. (…) Coexistence is only possible between people reduced to a negative or hollow presence, which constantly gives way. Hence, the emptiness of society, an immense ghost made up of countless dead people. A superior man is antisocial or criminal. His destiny is prison and the desert». I hesitate to think whether Pascoaes reflects here on the political-social conditions that muzzle, and, worse, in a sad country like Portugal in the middle of the Estado Novo (and the book is from 1931) where any possibilities of spontaneity and frankness in human relationships were restricted, or if it merely lends to the behavior of (oppressed) men a metaphysical framework, an “essence”, declared in the presumption of each being, in isolation, “one and absolute”. Sometimes, in addition to an excess of Spirituality (or Saudade), Pascoaes lacks the world. He is a great poet, but he is a poet who takes Ampoules-of-Great-Ideas and who therefore writes often trapped by a programmatic furor, ceasing to have pores; It is not uncommon for a glass to be erected between him and reality, the same glass that made him write in O Bailado, from 1921: «Everything is a ghost. There are only clouds, clouds of voices, clouds of souls, of afflictions and tragedies! Clouds and more clouds, appearances and more appearances! And a divine lightning that pierces them, the instantaneous Apparition that appears and throws us to the ground, dazzled!» Sometimes I felt like reminding him, as António Sérgio did, in the article “Regeneration and Tradition, Moral and Economy”, which he dedicated to Pascoaes: «Pascoais, Pascoais my dear friend: you are a pure, excellent and noble poet, but also a victim of this social environment, like us all: of this horrible isolation that you praise and I curse». «As a child, he stole two blackbirds», says Jacinto do Prado Coelho, he stole them from a nest, and he felt remorse for that all his life. The Person, few more mischiefs are known to him. Only in Álvaro de Campos does a hint of wickedness and obscenity emerge: «Ah, and the ordinary and dirty people, who always look the same,/ Who use swear words as usual words,/ Whose sons steal from grocery store doors/ And whose daughters at the age of eight – and I think this is beautiful and I love it! –/ Decent-looking men masturbate in stairwells.” (Triumphal ode). Both poets, driven by a certain idea of ​​sanctity, had the same inability to break the siege of their skin with the overflow of someone else's dam, the same curse of sublimating the concrete ferocity of eros with the gentleness of the verses. Obviously, they are both “bigger than life”, but sometimes it makes me unnerved to watch, from my position as a hatter at the Procrastinators Club, the tantrums between them, just to see who occupies, in the internal organization, the position of President and Treasurer. Although Pessoa guessed more things, for example, what he wrote in the lesser-known Ode Martial and which is reflected in the situation we live in today, in a different way, with his heart in his hands: «MARTIAL ODE (…) Helahoho! helahoho! The poor widow's sewing machine who was bayoneted... She sewed indefinitely in the afternoon… A mesa onde jogavam os velhos, Everything mixed, everything mixed with bodies, with blood, All one river, one wave, one dragging horror. Helahoho! helahoho! I unearthed the child's tin train pressed into the middle of the [road, And I cried like all the mothers in the world about the horror of life. My pantheistic feet tripped over the sewing machine [widow who was killed with a bayonet And that poor instrument of peace stuck a spear in my heart. Yes, I was the one to blame for everything, I was the soldier for them all Who killed, raped, burned and broke, It was me and my shame and my remorse like a shadow [misshapen They travel around the world like Ashavero, But behind my steps there are footsteps the size of infinity And a physical fear of being accountable to God makes me close my eyes. [eyes suddenly. (…) I ordered, captain, to shoot the trembling peasants, I let the daughters of all fathers tied to trees be raped, Now I saw that it was inside my heart that all this happened, And everything scalds and suffocates and I can't move without it [everything be the same. God have mercy on me, I didn't have it from anyone! LÀ-BAS, JE NE SAIS OÙ…” What is clear today, at this disastrous moment in which Cristiano & Companhia failed in their mission in Braga, and in which the self-sabotage of Russia's gas pipelines reminds us that Putin will indeed be willing to do anything to maintain dominance over the areas endorsed, is that, bomb for bomb, the “bomb” of the Fifth Empire was preferable. However, even in this, my dears, we were irresolute, a little more on the side of piela than determined, and we procrastinated.

item.title: Economy | Historic US allies cede influence to China
item.description: The leaders of the United Kingdom and Canada “bowed to Beijing”, observed analyst Bill Bishop yesterday, in an analysis of recent diplomatic contacts with China, which reflect a distance from the United States. “We had two of the United States' staunchest historical allies, two members of NATO […] effectively, in a way, bowing down to Beijing”, commented the analyst in his daily bulletin Sinocism. Last week's visit by British Prime Minister Keir Starmer to the People's Republic of China – the first by a British head of government since 2018 – comes at a time when other Western leaders, such as those from France, Finland and Canada, are also seeking to strengthen ties with Beijing, in a trend towards diversifying alliances in the face of the unpredictability of North American foreign policy. Although Beijing did not announce any major concessions to the British delegation, Starmer returned to the United Kingdom with a reduction in tariffs on British whiskey from 10 percent to 5 percent and with the promise of new commercial partnerships. A business delegation of around 50 companies, including AstraZeneca, accompanied the head of Government, and an investment of 15 billion dollars in China until 2030 was announced. The visit was preceded by the approval, by the British authorities, of a project for a new Chinese embassy in London, blocked for several years, as well as the abandonment of a judicial process for espionage involving Chinese citizens. For Bishop, Beijing's strategy does not aim to replace the United States as these countries' main ally, but rather to “explore the space left by fissures” in traditional relations with Washington. Starmer's visit, like that of the Canadian Prime Minister, is interpreted as a sign of openness to more pragmatic relations with two members of NATO and the “Five Eyes” information alliance. “China continues to have a huge advantage in critical supply chains, such as rare earths,” recalled Bishop, referring to Chinese control over minerals essential to the industry. A recent report by the European Council on Foreign Relations (ECFR) think tank pointed in a similar direction. The document concluded that Donald Trump's unilateral and transactional foreign policy is causing a global realignment, with several countries considering China a more predictable and, in some cases, more trustworthy actor than the United States. Influence Maps According to ECFR, only 16 percent of Europeans today see the US as a reliable ally. Among respondents in 21 countries, only 10 percent believe that the US will have more influence in the world within 10 years, while 36 percent believe in China. The report also highlighted that many citizens, both in Europe and in the so-called Global South, no longer see the world divided between two rival blocs, but rather as a multipolar space, where it is possible to maintain good relations with both powers. For Bishop, China's objective is not to turn Western allies against Washington, but rather to take advantage of the divisions that have widened. “It’s not about turning them against the United States, but rather about expanding the space for influence and negotiation,” he stated.

item.title: Mineral trade | Beijing rejects fragmentation after US initiative
item.description: China yesterday rejected the creation of exclusive “small circles” in international trade in critical minerals and advocated an “open, inclusive and universally beneficial” trading environment, in response to US-led initiatives. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian said at a press conference that “maintaining an open, inclusive and universally beneficial international trade environment serves the common interests of all countries”. Lin further stressed that “all parties have a responsibility to play a constructive role” to safeguard the stability and security of global production and supply chains for critical minerals. The spokesperson added that China “opposes any country harming the international economic and commercial order through exclusive ‘small circles’ rules”, in an indirect reference to the cooperation mechanisms promoted by Washington with partners and allies to reduce China's dependence in this sector. The statements come after the United States announced the creation of a commercial alliance for critical minerals and Washington and the European Union agreed on a first joint action plan to coordinate supply policies for these raw materials, considered essential for industries such as semiconductors, advanced batteries and defense. Beijing reiterated in recent days that its position on the stability of global supply chains “has not changed” and defended the strengthening of communication and dialogue between countries, to the detriment of formulas that “fragment international trade”.

item.title: Report | Direct investment abroad reaches maximum since 2018
item.description: China invested around US$124 billion abroad in 2025, the highest amount in new agreements since 2018, North American consultancy Rhodium Group said yesterday. Although it remains far from the historic record of US$287 billion recorded in 2016, the total value was driven by new generation projects in the mining, data center and energy sectors, which together represented around US$100 billion last year. The report also highlights that actually completed operations amounted to US$73 billion – the highest value since 2019 –, reflecting the usual delay between the announcement and completion of investments, as well as the cancellation of some projects. According to Rhodium, although China continues to invest heavily in overseas factories, the trend is declining. On the contrary, exports continue to be the main driver of Chinese economic globalization. “Chinese companies may be localizing part of their production through foreign direct investment, but China’s globalization strategy continues to focus on exports,” says the report, which adds that “domestic production capacity has grown much faster than outside China since the pandemic.” North Africa was the only region in the world to record an increase in Chinese investment in new manufacturing units during 2025, which could represent “a disappointment” for countries that hoped to revitalize the industry with capital from China. Main role Asia remained, in 2025, the main destination for Chinese foreign investment, followed by markets such as Latin America, driven by mining and infrastructure projects. In contrast, the share of investments in North America, Europe and Oceania fell from around 70 percent of the total in 2016 to less than 20 percent. The decline was particularly pronounced in Central and Eastern Europe, highlights the consultant, who associates the decline with Beijing's reluctance to allow advanced Chinese technologies to be transferred abroad. The automotive sector represented 13 percent of investment, the lowest share since 2020, due to the slowdown in electric vehicle production chains. In the opposite direction, investments in iron, lithium and gold exploration projects, as well as in fossil and renewable energy, increased. The report also highlights the growth of digital services, the second largest in the historical series, with emphasis on the “boom” of data centers in Southeast Asia, and the consumer goods sector, driven by the acquisition of historic European brands and retail networks. Rhodium Group's estimate differs from official data released by Beijing, which points to US$174.4 billion invested abroad in 2025, 7.1 percent more than in the previous year. The difference, according to the consultant, is due to Chinese companies that maintain revenues in dollars in their branches abroad, avoiding repatriating profits and converting them into assets denominated in renmimbi.

item.title: China | Veteran investigative reporter detained
item.description: A veteran Chinese investigative journalist was detained by authorities in Sichuan province, in southwest China, after publishing an article critical of the actions of local leaders, local press reported yesterday. The police in Jinjiang district, in Chengdu, the provincial capital, reported on Monday, via social media, that two people, identified only by the surnames Liu (50 years old) and Wu (34 years old), were placed under “criminal coercive measures in accordance with the law”, on suspicion of “false accusations” and “illegal commercial operations”. According to the Chinese newspaper Caixin, the detainees are journalist Liu Hu and his assistant, Wu Lingjiao. Liu Hu is known for his work as an investigative reporter for the Guangzhou-based newspaper New Express. In recent years, he has maintained a social media account where he publishes independent reports, mainly on conflicts between private companies and local authorities. Last Thursday, Liu published an article, which has since been deleted, in which he cited a source who accused Pu Fayou, secretary of the Communist Party in Pujiang town (under the jurisdiction of Chengdu), of abuse of power and repression of local businesspeople. The article also referenced Pu's alleged connection to the forced demolition of two properties owned by university professor Tuo Jiguang, who committed suicide in 2021 after prolonged litigation with authorities. Quoted by the Hong Kong newspaper South China Morning Post, an official from the Party committee in Pujiang confirmed that a joint investigation team has been set up between Chengdu and Pujiang, saying that the authorities “are giving high priority” to the allegations made by Liu. However, he declined to provide further details.

item.title: Depression Kristin | Timor-Leste approves donation of 4.2 million euros to support Portugal
item.description: The Government of Timor-Leste approved yesterday, in the council of ministers, a donation of 4.2 million euros in support to Portugal to face the destruction that occurred following the Kristin depression. “This financial support aims to contribute to the immediate response and recovery efforts of the most affected areas”, can be read in the statement from the council of ministers. Ten people have died since last week following bad weather. Civil Protection recorded five deaths directly associated with the passage of the Kristin depression and the Câmara da Marinha Grande announced another fatality, to which were added four deaths recorded due to falls from roofs (during repairs) or poisoning originating from a generator. The total or partial destruction of homes, businesses and equipment, falling trees and structures, cuts or restrictions on roads and transport services, especially railway lines, the closure of schools and power, water and communications cuts are the main material consequences of the storm, which caused hundreds of injuries and displacement. Leiria, Coimbra and Santarém are the districts with the most damage. The Government declared a state of calamity until next Sunday for 68 municipalities and announced a package of support measures of up to 2.5 billion euros.

item.title: Japan | Heavy snow kills 35 people
item.description: Heavy snowfall has killed 35 people in Japan in the last two weeks, especially in the Niigata region, the center of the archipelago, Japanese authorities announced yesterday. A total of 15 municipalities were affected, with the amount of snow accumulated in the most affected areas being estimated at two meters high. In Niigata, a rice-producing region in northern Japan, deaths were reported, including a 50-year-old man who was found lying on the roof of his home in the city of Uonuma on January 21. In the city of Nagaoka, a 70-year-old man was found lying in front of his home and urgently taken to the hospital, where he was pronounced dead. Niigata authorities believe the elderly man fell from the roof while clearing snow. Seven snow-related deaths were also reported in Akita Prefecture and five in Yamagata Prefecture. The number of injured across the country reached 393, including 126 with serious injuries, 42 of them in Niigata. Fourteen houses were damaged, three in Niigata and eight in Aomori Prefecture, where up to 4.5 meters of snow accumulated in isolated areas. A strong cold air mass has brought heavy snowfall in recent weeks along the Sea of ​​Japan coast, with some areas receiving more than double the usual amount of snow. A Japanese government spokesman warned that although temperatures are rising, new dangers could emerge as snow would begin to melt, resulting in landslides and slippery surfaces. “Please pay close attention to your safety by wearing a helmet or safety rope, especially when working in snow removal,” Minoru Kihara told reporters. Elections on the way The Government of Japan has created several task forces to respond to heavy snowfall in Niigata and nearby regions since January 20. Snow-related deaths and accidents are not uncommon in Japan, with 68 deaths recorded during the previous six months of winter, according to the Japanese Fire and Disaster Management Agency. More heavy snow is forecast for the weekend, with the country holding early general elections on Sunday. Japanese public broadcaster NHK said several agencies were working to ensure the elections ran without incident, and authorities urged voters to exercise caution and check weather conditions before traveling to vote, including during the early voting period. According to the most recent polls, Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi is on track for a landslide victory in the elections, called by the conservative leader just two weeks ago to take advantage of high approval ratings and reinforce the popular mandate for her new coalition government. This will be the first time since the 1990s that Japan has held early elections.

item.title: EU | Beijing denounces “protectionism” after investigation into wind manufacturer Goldwind
item.description: China yesterday accused the European Union of protectionism for opening an investigation into wind energy manufacturer Goldwind for alleged state subsidies, warning that these types of measures “undermine the confidence” of Chinese companies in Europe. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian urged Brussels to respect its market opening commitments and the principles of fair competition, calling for an end to the “abuse of unilateral trade instruments”, while defending a “fair, transparent and non-discriminatory” business environment for companies from all countries. Lin declined to comment on the specific case, referring any clarifications to the Chinese “competent authorities”, but stated that the European Union has repeatedly resorted to “discriminatory and restrictive” measures against Chinese companies, which, according to him, harms the bloc's image and affects the availability of Chinese companies to invest in Europe. The spokesperson also reiterated that Beijing “will firmly safeguard the legitimate and legal rights and interests of Chinese companies”, in line with the position taken by China in other commercial processes initiated by the EU in sectors considered strategic. The Chinese reaction comes after the European Commission announced the opening of an investigation into the Chinese wind turbine manufacturer Goldwind, over suspicions that subsidies granted by Beijing – such as direct support, tax benefits or financing under favorable conditions – could distort competition in the EU's internal market. Goldwind operates in several European countries through subsidiaries, including the German Vensys, developing activities in the EU that range from turbine production to research, maintenance and management services for wind farms.

item.title: Diplomacy | Xi talks via video conference with Putin
item.description: Chinese President Xi Jinping held a videoconference conversation yesterday with his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin, reported the official Chinese news agency Xinhua, without revealing, for now, the content of the meeting. China and Russia maintain strong economic, diplomatic and military ties, which have intensified since Russia's invasion of Ukraine in 2022. Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin exchanged congratulatory messages on the occasion of the New Year on December 31st. The two leaders met at the beginning of September, in Beijing, on the sidelines of the military parade organized by China to mark 80 years since the victory over Japan in the Second World War. This new conversation between Xi and Putin comes at a time when the United States claims to be close to reaching an agreement to end the conflict in Ukraine. Russians and Ukrainians continue today with the meetings that began yesterday for new rounds of negotiations in Abu Dhabi, in the United Arab Emirates. China presents itself as a neutral party in this conflict and claims not to provide lethal aid to either side, unlike the United States and other Western countries.

item.title: Meeting | PCC and Taiwanese opposition reinforce notion of common nation
item.description: The representative of the Taiwanese opposition reiterated the Kuomintang's commitment to the well-being of the common Chinese nation at a meeting with leaders in Beijing The leader of China's main consultative body, Wang Huning, and an opposition representative in Taiwan yesterday highlighted the notion of a “common Chinese nation” between the two sides of the Strait, at a meeting in Beijing. The leader of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference defended that the inhabitants of both sides of the Taiwan Strait have “common responsibilities towards the Chinese nation”, in the meeting with Hsiao Hsu-tsen, vice-president of the Kuomintang (KMT), in the context of an apparent rapprochement effort between the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) and the main opposition party in Taiwan, which goes against the cycle of growing tension between Beijing and Taipei. Wang assured that holding the recent think tank forum between the two parties demonstrates “the commitment of both parties to the well-being of citizens on both sides” and contributes “positive energy” to cross-strait relations. “The inhabitants of both sides of the Taiwan Strait belong to the Chinese nation”, share “the same blood, the same culture and the same history” and have “common responsibilities towards the nation and shared aspirations for the future”, he stressed. Hsiao reinforced that the so-called 1992 Consensus and the opposition to Taiwan's independence “constitute the common political basis that allows exchanges between both parties to be maintained”. The leader went further by reformulating the original understanding of the agreement, stating that “each party expresses a single China”, thus rejecting the idea of ​​“different interpretations” of the concept. “Chinese consciousness is our soul, Chinese culture is our body and the Chinese nation is our root,” declared Hsiao, in a symbolic gesture of political alignment with Beijing. One country The meeting took place in the Xinjiang Hall of the Grand Palace of the People, in Beijing, according to the Taiwanese news agency CNA, one day after the forum that marked the resumption of institutional exchange between the CCP and the KMT, interrupted almost a decade ago. The event is seen as a preliminary step towards a possible meeting between Xi Jinping and the new KMT president, Cheng Li-wun, scheduled for the first half of this year. The 1992 Consensus is a tacit understanding under which both Beijing and Taipei recognize the existence of ‘one China’, although they disagree on what that means. This ambiguity allowed, for decades, dialogue between the continent and the island. The harmony between the PCC and the KMT contrasts sharply with the hostile climate between the Chinese Government and the Taiwanese Executive, led since 2016 by the Democratic Progressive Party - a formation that rejects 'reunification' with China and argues that the political future of the island rests exclusively with its 23 million inhabitants.

item.title: Marcelo Loureiro, author and teacher: “The indigenato was a continuation of slavery”
item.description: Esteve recentemente em Macau para apresentar o livro “Colonial Citizenship: law, race and rights through the Portuguese empire”. A obra de Marcelo Loureiro explora a forma como, no império português, a cidadania portuguesa foi sendo moldada conforme a cor da pele. Macau não foi excepção, ainda que com outros contornos face a África, argumenta o docente da Universidade de Leicester Image: Rui Cunha Foundation How did this investigation begin and how did the themes of colonialism and citizenship emerge? Everything was born from a personal and family experience. I grew up in Rio de Janeiro, in a family marked by the Portuguese diaspora on the one hand, and colonial silence on the other. My paternal grandmother, Portuguese, kept the documents that allowed me, at the age of thirteen, to claim Portuguese citizenship in the back of a closet. My other grandmother, mestizo, cafuza, had no papers, no stories to tell; From her to me, there was only silence. This division, between those who have the right to documents and a voice and those who are forced to be erased, was the starting point for questioning the legal construction of citizenship and nationality. When I arrived in Portugal to study Law in Coimbra, I began to realize that the law that recognized me as Portuguese was the same one that historically denied this recognition to millions of people based on race, 'civilization' and skin color. The book is, in part, an attempt to understand this legal structure of inclusion and exclusion, it is a denunciation of the injustice behind rights. It is a denunciation of citizenship as a method of exclusion. In the context of the Portuguese empire, when did the first notions of citizenship emerge and what criteria were used? The first formal notions of national belonging in Portugal appear in the Philippine Ordinances of 1603, which establish who should be considered 'natural' of the kingdom. It is interesting to note that the inclusion of the notion of nationality was only included in Portuguese law during the Iberian Union, during the Philippine dynasty, when Spain controlled Portugal through the Habsburgs. It was in this context that Spanish law was transposed to Portugal to separate Portuguese from Spanish. However, the practical construction of Portuguese citizenship begins much earlier, in opposition: through slavery. Since the 15th century, with papal bulls (such as Dum Diversas of 1452 and Romanus Pontifex of 1454), Portugal obtained canonical legitimacy to enslave Africans and conquer their territories. Portuguese citizenship was thus constructed, in opposition to the figure of the ‘other’ – the Moor, the black, the pagan, the ‘savage’, and finally, the ‘indigenous’. What were the differentiation criteria? The criteria were essentially civilizational and racial: being Christian and, progressively, being white or recognized as ‘civilized’ according to European standards. Conversion to Christianity functioned, at times, as a kind of 'spiritual whitening', but even converts rarely achieved full legal equality, which continued to be imposed for centuries. The law called indigenous to all those who existed outside the standard of civilization expected of citizens, which were the non-white populations of Angola, Mozambique, Guinea and Timor. Macau will always have occupied a “privileged position” in the context of this empire. Specifically, how? In terms of citizenship, Macau has never been subject to the Indigenous Statute, which was in force in Angola, Mozambique, Guinea and Timor. This exclusion was not accidental. The Indigenous Statute applied to populations considered 'uncivilized' according to European racial and cultural criteria, being, in practical terms, essentially black populations from continental Africa and Timor. In Macau, the Chinese population, often called ‘Macau Chins’, although not European, were treated differently. There were laws that regulated the rights and customs of the Macanese population, with a complete law coming into force in 1909 and only abolished in 1949, for example. The Portuguese presence in Macau has always been accompanied by several other factors, such as British influence through contact with Hong Kong, the progressive political presence of Beijing, Portuguese political instability and the questioning of the existence of the Portuguese empire itself internationally. This meant that Portugal was unable to impose in Macau a sovereignty as powerful as that imposed in Africa and Timor. Were there cases of discrimination against the Chinese and Macanese communities before the 20th century? Discrimination existed, although of a different nature than that imposed in Africa. We can even see in literature, in the works of Senna Fernandes, for example, how the existence of walls, sides and parts of Macau, sometimes even ideological, for different populations, from Chinese villages to Christian cities. The same division occurred in the world of rights, only in an indirect way, and not through the direct imposition of indigeneity and the status of second-class national. Segregation and difference occurred socially, with difficulty accessing certain careers, the lack of invitations to birthdays because they were not ‘white’. This discrimination did not take the systematic legal form of indigeneity, as stated. The Macanese occupied an intermediate position, often functioning as intermediaries between the Portuguese and Chinese. Their ‘Portugueseness’ was recognized in an ambiguous way: they were Portuguese, but of a different type. We can mention that skin color was decisive in not placing Macau under the Indigenous Statute. Yes, skin color was absolutely decisive. The Indigenous Statute was applied in Angola, Mozambique, Guinea and Timor, territories with populations that are mostly black or ‘non-white’ in the colonial sense. Portuguese law even created the term 'oceanic race' to identify Timorese during the imposition of indigenato so that they could bring this population racially closer to African populations. Macau, Portuguese India, Cape Verde, and, to a certain extent, São Tomé and Príncipe, were excluded from this classification. The official criteria established 'uses and customs' and 'civilization' as the parameters to identify these people, but in reality these categories only functioned as a substitute for race: they were race, but by another name. The populations of Portuguese India and Macau, although not European, have always been spared the application of openly racist laws, despite local practices and policies imposing, most often indirectly, restrictions on the full citizenship of these populations, as I have described. Taking into account the Indigenous Statute, what evolution can you trace in terms of the concept of Portuguese citizenship? The Indigenous Statute, consolidated in the early 1930s, represented the maximum legal codification of racial exclusion. Indigenato was a legal form of racial segregation that created two categories of being Portuguese, namely being a Portuguese citizen (white and assimilated) and being indigenous Portuguese (the majority black). The indigenous people were legally Portuguese, but they were not citizens; they did not live with access to rights, but to restrictions, they lived, as I call it in the book, in a status of ‘negatory nationality’. Indigenous people could not vote, could not move freely, did not have the right to lawyers, were subject to forced labor, paid special taxes based on race, and could not attend the same schools or hospitals as whites. The evolution of the concept of Portuguese citizenship in this context is paradoxical: formally, everyone was ‘Portuguese’, but materially, citizenship was reserved for those who demonstrated ‘civilization’ through skin color or by proving themselves to be sufficiently assimilated despite being black. Assimilation was the only legal path to leaving indigeneity, but it required proving mastery of the Portuguese language, abandonment of African ‘uses and customs’, stable employment, ‘good moral conduct’, and military service. Very few could. What are the most flagrant cases of denial of rights that you can point to? One of the most flagrant is the system of forced labor, which functioned as a continuation of slavery under another name. Indigenous people were forced to work on plantations, mines and public works, often far from their families, in inhumane conditions. Another case is spatial and social segregation: separate hospitals for whites and indigenous people, segregated neighborhoods, different schools. In Guinea, indigenous people were forced to wear necklaces with metal plates. In Mozambique they were forced to pay radio taxes if they had a device. In Timor they were required to pay taxes if they moved from one local authority to another, or when they divorced according to local customs. The archives also show cases of indigenous people who, despite having moved to Lisbon, still continued to be treated as indigenous people. All thanks to a 1955 law that imposed indigenato status on any indigenous person in any part of the Portuguese empire – which was previously only applied in indigenato colonies. This was the case of the so-called ‘Lisbon Requests’, a group of assimilation applications that I found in the Lisbon Ultramarine Archive, where indigenous people who, having emigrated to the metropolis, tried to obtain recognition as citizens. The Indigenous Statute would be abolished years later, but the effects seem to have remained. I absolutely agree. And I say more: indigenato was a continuation of slavery itself, a reflection that is still felt today by so many communities touched by the Portuguese empire. The Statute was abolished in 1961, but decades of legal, educational and economic exclusion are not erased by decree. African populations have been systematically denied access to education, property, mobility and political participation for generations. This explains, to a certain extent, the difference between the different parts of the Portuguese empire, where Brazil, Angola, Macau and India occupy completely different spectrums in relation to levels of protection and access to rights. When the Statute was abolished, a context of restriction and necessity was already consolidated where the black majority survived without formal education and without access to basic rights. The post-colonial effects are equally profound: indigenato taught generations of Africans that their culture, language and way of life were inferior, and that to formally be someone, to be recognized as fully human before the law, they had to become white, they had to resemble, as much as possible, the colonizer. But even this formal assimilation rarely translated into real protection: legal recognition did not guarantee effective access to rights. Assimilation marks not only a historical period, but a way of seeing, feeling and surviving colonial history. This violence left marks that persist in Portuguese-speaking post-colonial societies and that can only be resolved when there is a process of acceptance, truth and reconstruction — something that the Portuguese State has not yet been able to do.

item.title: Exhibition | Eric Fok shows “Dreaming of the Occident” in Taiwan: “In Portugal, I see traces of my city”
item.description: The year began with a new project by Eric Fok, who despite living in Portugal did not leave Macau and the East. “Dreaming of the Occident” is on display at the Helios gallery, in Taipei, and can be seen until January 24th. To HM, the local artist reveals that he wants to artistically explore the universe of Vendas Novas bifana, through its connection to Macau pork chop How is the West represented in this exhibition? I've always been fascinated by the intersection between Eastern and Western cultures, and I've explored how Macau was a territory shaped by Western missionaries and navigators who brought new sciences and ideas to the East. Regarding a previous exhibition, and during the research process, I realized how rare it was for the Chinese to travel to Europe at the time of the Discoveries. I read with enthusiasm the reports of the few who did so. There are diaries that vividly recreate the dangerous sea voyages and what life was like in ancient European cities. This allowed me to project myself into their stories, bridging the gap between past and present, between East and East. These cultural differences are not just history to me, but have become a rich source of imagination for my new work. As an artist from Macau, how has the history of the territory, marked by exchange between East and West, shaped your way of thinking about this exhibition? It all started with mapping Macau for the “Paraíso” series [2014 exhibition], a project that was born out of my curiosity about the city's past in a context of rapid expansion of the tourism and gaming industries. Through this dialogue with local history, I began to truly understand the city. I went from focusing on the small details of urban life to having a macro perspective of the world, highlighting Macau's significant role in global history. This includes its status as a gateway to China during the Discoveries, its contribution to the beginning of globalization, or even being a space for the spread of Catholicism to the East. [We cannot forget] the profound influence of maritime culture. All of these themes constitute an extension of my exploration of the historical and unique experience of Macau. Can you describe in more detail the creative process for “Dreaming of the Occident”? In addition to maps of Macau, this exhibition also presents maps of Eurasia and several Asian colonies, where I explore themes such as navigation, trade and empire. My research also extends to experimenting with materials. In addition to using paper and wood, I incorporated unconventional supports, such as ostrich eggs. These objects function as canvases to narrate stories about endemic species and the history of migration, establishing a bridge between a biological and historical side. Does the exhibition intend to criticize the Western influence in Macau, reflect on it or simply observe it? In my exploration of these themes I am mainly interested in the cultural dimensions of history. When Europeans first arrived in Asia, they viewed the world from a Eurocentric perspective. The term “Far East” was not just a geographical designation, but a symbol of power and a specific vision of the world. But, on the other hand, the term “Far West” represents an initial global imagination, in the sense of being a space of mutual understanding, albeit incomplete. Today, as we live in an era of a lot of information, where connectivity is instantaneous, we have lost that sense of mystery, and my work seeks to recover a little of what is the fantasy of distance. Do you expect different readings of the exhibition or a deeper knowledge of what Macau is, in cultural and historical terms? In the creative process, I privilege personal expression as responses to society and the world in which we live. Although exhibiting in a commercial gallery inevitably brings a market dimension to my work, my focus is always on the integrity of the work. In recent years, my desire for the public to “correctly decode” my art has changed, in the sense that, although I feel deep satisfaction when someone connects with my inner world, I have come to accept this “emptiness” in the narrative of my work. These gaps are meant to be filled by the experiences and emotions of the viewer, or perhaps by time and history itself. In a time of rapid and ephemeral changes, I use the brush to document and preserve. My work consists of sharing the urban experience that invites the public to create an emotional connection with cities, promoting a deep reflection on identity and belonging. He has lived between Macau and Portugal. How does this influence your work and vision of Macau’s history and culture? At the moment I respond to this interview I find myself in Vendas Novas, a town in Portugal that is famous for bifana. I am currently exploring whether there is any direct connection between this local specialty and Macau pork chop bread. Centuries ago, the Portuguese sought to build a “home” in Macau, leaving behind Portuguese structures that defined the skyline of my city. Currently, being in Portugal, I see traces of my city everywhere. Being Asian, and being surrounded by different races and languages, I find a certain sense of belonging that can be both alienating and deeply familiar. The enormous geographical distance is shortened by culture and history, which are shared. This exchange of identities and the movement between places constitute deep inspirations for my work. Searching for an unknown place On the Helios gallery's internet portal, Eric Fok's new exhibition is described as a search for a Europe that, on the eastern side, was known to exist, but which was far from being known, especially from the middle of the 16th century, when the term “Taixi” appeared as a reference to the “Great West”. The Chinese expression was used by the Jesuit missionary Matteo Ricci and is one of the focuses of the Macau artist's work in “Dreaming of the Occident”. According to Helios' presentation, “Taixi” was a term attributed to “an extremely distant land in the West that was, once, a blank space on maps, yet to be explored”. In this way, Eric Fok's imagined maps explore the ideas of an absent and unknown place, also analyzing “the identity of the self, the transport of memories, power and ideology”. Using historical research, the Macau artist “rediscovers ‘Taixi’ from the perspective of the Far East, through writing and cartographic representation”. Eric Fok also investigated “the views of the world that existed in the past, formed by the interconnection between power and belief”, it is described.

item.title: Iranian Ambassador in Lisbon condemned “institutionalization of the improper use of force”
item.description: Iran's ambassador in Lisbon, Majid Tafreshi, condemned the “institutionalization of a new policy”, implemented with the instrument of “improper use of force”, alluding to the United States and Israel. In an interview with the Lusa agency, Tafreshi warned that this process will “spread” if countries, especially Western ones, “do not take serious measures” against the United States and Israel, “which have incited public unrest”. “There are no guarantees that such practices will not be repeated, especially when disturbing discussions are already being heard, such as those regarding the possession of Greenland”, highlighted Tafreshi, remembering the North American actions in Venezuela, and the insinuations against Colombia and Cuba. The interview took place before the diplomat was called by the Portuguese Government because of the violent repression of demonstrations against the Iranian Government, an announcement made yesterday by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The Iranian diplomat recalled having already asked his “academic colleagues” and diplomats to create in Portugal a new forum entitled “Dialogue between Enemies”, in the search for “universal peace and a world free from war and tension”, as well as the creation of new mechanisms – such as an East Asian Union – “could constitute a meaningful initiative”. “I believe that politics and politicians should follow more closely the will of their own people, who, in reality, do not seem to have major conflicts between themselves – as can be clearly seen in tourism, in football stadiums, in concerts and in hundreds of other human interactions”, argued the Iranian diplomat. Regarding recent developments in Iran, in which, he said, peaceful demonstrations focused on economic challenges, over time, “some elements present in these concentrations escalated to violent incidents”, including armed actions that, according to reports, “involved individuals with prior training”. “Regrettably, these events resulted in casualties among security forces, public order forces and ordinary citizens,” said Tafreshi, after the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, Volker Türk, condemned and demanded an end to the “repression of protests in Iran, which have resulted in more than 600 deaths since December 28, according to a non-governmental organization. Iran's ambassador in Lisbon referred to the “millions of Iranian citizens” who participated in public demonstrations on Monday, “reflecting a change in the general picture and expressing support for their Islamic country”, which, as in the past, the news received limited attention from the Western media. Outside incentives Asked about what is strangling the Iranian economy, Tafreshi highlights the interventions of Israel, “to a lesser extent”, and the United States, “which have encouraged public unrest”, as well as Iran's economic challenges, which are significantly influenced by extensive sanctions imposed” by Washington. “These measures, which Iran considers illegal, have also been supported by European countries that defend human rights, despite there being concerns that such policies have negatively affected fundamental rights of the Iranian population, including access to healthcare”, he denounced. “Respect for the Charter of the United Nations, the bitter lessons of the First and Second World Wars and the devastating experiences and costs of events in Afghanistan, Syria, Palestine, Lebanon, Libya, Iraq, Ukraine and elsewhere should be enough to remind us of the urgent need to prioritize, more than ever, peaceful coexistence”, he added. Regarding the high number of fatalities, Tafreshi denied that Iranian security is using a disproportionate use of force, exemplifying, alongside the high number of deaths among civilians, the significant number of deaths and injuries among police officers”. People power Asked about the words of Reza Pahlavi – son of the former shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, deposed after the 1979 Islamic Revolution – in which he stated that he intends to return to Iran soon, Tafreshi considered that, with the “support of some Western and Zionist media”, he appears to be trying to play the role of a “Robin of the Woods”. "However, Robin Hood never called on ordinary people to resort to violence or violate international norms and principles, such as attacking embassies and diplomatic facilities. During his father's reign, despite Iran having the support of the United States and the West, the country lost its 14th province, Bahrain. Based on experience, the United States supports and exploits anyone capable of harming Iran's independence and security," he responded. Tafreshi denied, on the other hand, that the regime – “the term “regime is an illegitimate and biased expression” – is at risk, highlighting again “the millions” of Iranians who demonstrated on Monday in favor of Iran's sovereignty. “The Islamic Republic belongs to the people of Iran. Ayatollah [Ali] Khamenei is the leader of Iran and one of those citizens”, highlighted the diplomat, for whom China and Russia maintain “good relations” with Tehran, meaning it is not necessary to count on Beijing or Moscow to defend the country, which counts on its own people to protect its security and sovereignty.

item.title: Sofia Ferreira da Silva, author of a study on opera in the Mao years: “Silk Road was the biggest influence”
item.description: In “Singing the Revolution: The Role of Songs and Opera in the Spread of Communism in Mao Zedong's China”, Sofia Ferreira da Silva analyzes the way in which songs and opera spread political ideals, leaving marks on the country's cultural panorama. The analysis came from the doctoral thesis in Artistic Studies, defended by the author at Universidade Nova de Lisboa What was the musical environment like in the country before Mao Zedong came to power? China was, and continues to be, a territory with a huge variety of practices at regional, local and ethnic levels. We can speak of four main types: music of a more erudite nature, symbolized by court music (yayue) and guqin music, more centered on Confucian ideals and with ritual functions and self-cultivation of individual morality; folk music, with vocal and instrumental genres varying according to region and ethnicity; Taoist, Buddhist and other religious music; and traditional opera, such as Kunqu and Peking, Sichuan and Canton operas, combining singing, declamation, stylized movements and martial arts.
